**Lisbon** ([/ˈlɪzbən/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/5/5d/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Lisbon.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Lisbon.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Lisbon.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Lisbon.wav")^ [*LIZ-bən*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"); [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Lisboa* [\[liʒˈβoɐ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Portuguese "Help:IPA/Portuguese") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/d/d4/Pt-pt_Lisboa_FF.ogg/Pt-pt_Lisboa_FF.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Pt-pt_Lisboa_FF.ogg "File:Pt-pt Lisboa FF.ogg")^)^[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)^ is the capital and largest city of [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"), with an estimated population of 567,131 as of 2023 within its administrative limits^[\[3\]](#cite_note-dgt-3)^ and 2,961,177 within the [metropolis](/wiki/Lisbon_Metropolitan_Area "Lisbon Metropolitan Area").^[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)^ Lisbon is mainland [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe")'s westernmost capital city (second overall after [Reykjavik](/wiki/Reykjav%C3%ADk "Reykjavík")) and the only one along the Atlantic coast, the others (Reykjavik and [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin")) being on islands. The city lies in the western portion of the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula"), on the northern shore of the River [Tagus](/wiki/Tagus "Tagus"). The western portion of its metro area, the [Portuguese Riviera](/wiki/Portuguese_Riviera "Portuguese Riviera"), hosts the westernmost point of [Continental Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe"), culminating at [Cabo da Roca](/wiki/Cabo_da_Roca "Cabo da Roca").{#cite_ref-4}

Lisbon is one of the [oldest cities in the world](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities")^[\[5\]](#cite_note-RudlinThompsonJarvis2016-5)^ and the second-oldest European capital city (after [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens")), predating other modern European capitals by centuries.^[\[6\]](#cite_note-CIAFactbook2021-6)^ Settled by pre-Celtic tribes and later founded and civilized by the Phoenicians, [Julius Caesar](/wiki/Julius_Caesar "Julius Caesar") made it a [municipium](/wiki/Municipium "Municipium") called *Felicitas Julia* ,^[\[7\]](#cite_note-Livermore1973-7)^ adding the term to the name *[Olissipo](/wiki/Olisipo "Olisipo")* . After the [fall of the Roman Empire](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire "Fall of the Western Roman Empire"), it was ruled by a series of [Germanic tribes](/wiki/Germanic_peoples "Germanic peoples") from the 5th century, most notably the [Visigoths](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths"). Later it was captured by the [Moors](/wiki/Moors "Moors") in the 8th century. In 1147, [Afonso Henriques](/wiki/Afonso_Henriques "Afonso Henriques") [conquered the city](/wiki/Siege_of_Lisbon "Siege of Lisbon") and in 1255, it became [Portugal](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Portugal "Kingdom of Portugal")'s capital, replacing [Coimbra](/wiki/Coimbra "Coimbra").^[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)^ It has since been the political, economic, and cultural centre of the country.{#cite_ref-8}

As the political centre of the country, Lisbon hosts the [government](/wiki/Government_of_Portugal "Government of Portugal"), [National Assembly](/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_(Portugal) "Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)"), [Supreme Court of Justice](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Justice_(Portugal) "Supreme Court of Justice (Portugal)"), [Armed Forces](/wiki/Portuguese_Armed_Forces "Portuguese Armed Forces") and residence of the [head of state](/wiki/President_of_Portugal "President of Portugal"). It is also the centre of Portuguese diplomacy, with ambassadors from 86 countries residing in the city, as well as representations from [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") and [Palestine](/wiki/Palestine "Palestine").^[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)^ About 2.96 million people live in the [Lisbon metropolitan area](/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area "Lisbon metropolitan area"), which extends beyond the city's administrative area, making it the third largest metropolitan area in the [Iberian Peninsula](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") (after [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid") and [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona")) as well as figuring amongst the [10 most populous urban areas](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_European_Union "List of urban areas in the European Union") in the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").^[\[10\]](#cite_note-Statistics_Portugal_-_Web_Portal-10)^^[\[11\]](#cite_note-World_Urban_Areas-11)^ It represents approximately 28% of the country's population.{#cite_ref-World_Urban_Areas_11-0}

Lisbon is recognised as an [alpha-level global city](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network") because of its importance in finance, commerce, fashion, media, entertainment, arts, international trade, education, and tourism.^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^ Lisbon is amongst the two Portuguese cities (the other being [Porto](/wiki/Porto "Porto")) to be recognised as a global city, and it is also home to three companies in the [Global 2000](/wiki/Forbes_Global_2000 "Forbes Global 2000") ([EDP Group](/wiki/EDP_Group "EDP Group"), [Galp Energia](/wiki/Galp_Energia "Galp Energia") and [Jerónimo Martins](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_Martins "Jerónimo Martins")).^[\[14\]](#cite_note-GAWC-14)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-15)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^ Lisbon is one of the major economic centres in [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), with a growing financial sector, with [PSI-20](/wiki/Euronext_Lisbon "Euronext Lisbon") being part of [Euronext](/wiki/Euronext "Euronext"), the largest center for debt and funds listings in the world. The [Lisbon region](/wiki/Lisbon_region "Lisbon region") has a [higher GDP PPP per capita](/wiki/Economy_of_the_European_Union#Richest_&_Poorest_NUTS_Regions_(GDP_PPP_2007) "Economy of the European Union") than any other [region](/wiki/NUTS_II "NUTS II") in Portugal. Its GDP PPP amounts to US$179 billion and thus $61,713 per capita.{#cite_ref-16}

The city occupies the 40th place of highest gross earnings in the world and, with almost 21,000 millionaires, is the 11th European city by number of millionaires and the 14th by number of billionaires.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-17)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-18)^ Most of the headquarters of [multinational corporations](/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") in Portugal are located in the Lisbon area.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^{#cite_ref-19}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

Lisbon's name may derive from [Proto-Celtic](/wiki/Proto-Celtic "Proto-Celtic") or [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_languages "Celtic languages") *[Olisippo](/wiki/Olisippo "Olisippo")* , *Lissoppo* , or a similar name which other visiting ancient peoples such as the Phoenicians, Greeks, and Romans adapted accordingly, such as the pre-Roman appellation for the Tagus River, *Lisso* or *Lucio* . Classical authors writing in Latin and Greek, including [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo"), [Solinus](/wiki/Gaius_Julius_Solinus "Gaius Julius Solinus"), and [Martianus Capella](/wiki/Martianus_Capella "Martianus Capella"),^[\[20\]](#cite_note-BostockRiley2015-20)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-StahlBurge1992-21)^ referred to popular legends that the city of Lisbon was founded by the mythical hero Ulysses ([Odysseus](/wiki/Odysseus "Odysseus")).^[\[22\]](#cite_note-DelmasPenn2012-22)^^[\[23\]](#cite_note-Barletta2010-23)^ Lisbon's name was written *Ulyssippo* in Latin by the geographer [Pomponius Mela](/wiki/Pomponius_Mela "Pomponius Mela"), a native of [Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania"). It was later referred to as "Olisippo" by [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder") and by the Greeks as *Olissipo* (Ὀλισσιπών) or *Olissipona* (Ὀλισσιπόνα).^[\[24\]](#cite_note-Almeida1992-24)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^{#cite_ref-25}

Another claim repeated in historical literature is that the name of Lisbon could originate from a supposed ancient Phoenician term *Alis-Ubbo* , meaning "safe harbour" or "pleasant haven".^[\[26\]](#cite_note-History1780-26)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-FerreiraCabello1998-27)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Jack2019-28)^ Although modern archaeological excavations show there may have been Phoenician presence at this location since 1000 BC,^[\[29\]](#cite_note-Whitfield2005-29)^ this folk etymology completely lacks any evidence and "is never attested in ancient classical literature".^[\[30\]](#cite_note-Burstein2019-30)^{#cite_ref-Burstein2019_30-0}

Lisbon's name is commonly abbreviated as "LX" or "Lx", originating in an antiquated spelling of Lisbon as *Lixbõa* .^[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)^ While the old spelling has since been completely dropped from usage and goes against modern language standards, the abbreviation is still commonly used.{#cite_ref-31}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Lisbon](/wiki/History_of_Lisbon "History of Lisbon")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Lisbon](/wiki/Timeline_of_Lisbon "Timeline of Lisbon").  

### Origins {#Origins}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Origins")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Escava%C3%A7%C3%B5es_no_Claustro_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa.jpg/220px-Escava%C3%A7%C3%B5es_no_Claustro_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Escava%C3%A7%C3%B5es_no_Claustro_da_S%C3%A9_de_Lisboa.jpg) Phoenician archaeological dig in a cloister of the [Lisbon Cathedral](/wiki/Lisbon_Cathedral "Lisbon Cathedral")

During the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") period, the region was inhabited by Pre-Celtic tribes, who built religious and funerary monuments, [megaliths](/wiki/Megalith "Megalith"), [dolmens](/wiki/Dolmen "Dolmen") and [menhirs](/wiki/Menhir "Menhir"), which still survive in areas on the periphery of Lisbon.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^ The [Indo-European](/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-European languages") [Celts](/wiki/Celt "Celt") invaded in the 1st millennium BC, mixing with the [Pre-Indo-European](/wiki/Pre-Roman_peoples_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula "Pre-Roman peoples of the Iberian Peninsula") population, thus giving rise to Celtic-speaking local tribes such as the Cempsi or [Sefes](/wiki/Sefes "Sefes").{#cite_ref-32}

Although the first fortifications on Lisbon's [Castelo](/wiki/Castelo_de_S%C3%A3o_Jorge "Castelo de São Jorge") hill are known to be no older than the 2nd century BC, recent archaeological finds have shown that [Iron Age](/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") people occupied the site from the 8th to 6th centuries BC.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Bellard2003-33)^^[\[34\]](#cite_note-Arruda2002-34)^^[\[35\]](#cite_note-Laidlar1997-35)^ This indigenous settlement maintained commercial relations with the Phoenicians, which would account for the recent findings of Phoenician pottery and other material objects. Archaeological excavations made near the [Castle of São Jorge](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle "São Jorge Castle") (*Castelo de São Jorge* ) and [Lisbon Cathedral](/wiki/Lisbon_Cathedral "Lisbon Cathedral") indicate there may have been a Phoenician presence at this location since 1000 BC,^[\[29\]](#cite_note-Whitfield2005-29)^ and it can be stated with confidence that a Phoenician trading post stood on a site^[\[36\]](#cite_note-Pilkington2013-36)^^[\[37\]](#cite_note-WrightSwift1971-37)^ now the centre of the present city, on the southern slope of the Castle hill.^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^ The sheltered harbour in the [Tagus River](/wiki/Tagus_River "Tagus River") [estuary](/wiki/Estuary "Estuary") was an ideal spot for an [Iberian](/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula "Iberian Peninsula") settlement and would have provided a secure harbour for unloading and provisioning trading ships.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-PereiraMata2012-39)^ The Tagus settlement was an important centre of commercial trade with the inland tribes, providing an outlet for the valuable metals, salt and salted-fish they collected, and for the sale of the [Lusitanian horses](/wiki/Lusitano "Lusitano") renowned in antiquity.{#cite_ref-PereiraMata2012_39-0}

According to a persistent legend, the location was named for the Greek mythical king of Ithaca, [Ulysses](/wiki/Odysseus "Odysseus"), who founded the city when he sailed westward to the ends of the known world.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-Jack2019-28)^{#cite_ref-Jack2019_28-1}  

### Roman era {#Roman_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Roman era")\]  
Main article: [Olisipo](/wiki/Olisipo "Olisipo")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/CercaMouraTorreAlfama_%28cropped%29.JPG/220px-CercaMouraTorreAlfama_%28cropped%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:CercaMouraTorreAlfama_(cropped).JPG) Part of the *Cerca Velha* (Old Wall), originally built by the Romans^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^

Following the defeat of [Hannibal](/wiki/Hannibal "Hannibal") in 202 BC during the [Punic wars](/wiki/Punic_wars "Punic wars"), the Romans determined to deprive [Carthage](/wiki/Carthage "Carthage") of its most valuable possession: [Hispania](/wiki/Hispania "Hispania") (the Iberian Peninsula). The defeat of Carthaginian forces by [Scipio Africanus](/wiki/Scipio_Africanus "Scipio Africanus") in Eastern Hispania allowed the pacification of the west, led by Consul [Decimus Junius Brutus Callaicus](/wiki/Decimus_Junius_Brutus_Callaicus "Decimus Junius Brutus Callaicus"). Decimus obtained the alliance of [Olissipo](/wiki/Olisipo "Olisipo") (which sent men to fight alongside the Roman Legions against the northwestern Celtic tribes) by integrating it into the empire, as the *Municipium Cives Romanorum Felicitas Julia* . Local authorities were granted self-rule over a territory that extended 50 km (31 mi); exempt from taxes, its citizens were given the privileges of Roman citizenship,^[\[7\]](#cite_note-Livermore1973-7)^ and it was then integrated with the Roman province of [Lusitania](/wiki/Lusitania "Lusitania") (whose capital was [Emerita Augusta](/wiki/Emerita_Augusta "Emerita Augusta")).{#cite_ref-Livermore1973_7-1}

[Lusitanian](/wiki/Lusitanians "Lusitanians") raids and rebellions during Roman occupation required the construction of a wall around the settlement. During [Augustus](/wiki/Augustus "Augustus")' reign, the Romans also built a great theatre; the Cassian Baths (underneath *Rua da Prata* ); temples to [Jupiter](/wiki/Jupiter_(mythology) "Jupiter (mythology)"), [Diana](/wiki/Diana_(mythology) "Diana (mythology)"), [Cybele](/wiki/Cybele "Cybele"), [Tethys](/wiki/Tethys_(mythology) "Tethys (mythology)") and Idea [Phrygiae](/wiki/Phrygia "Phrygia") (an uncommon cult from [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor")), in addition to temples to the Emperor; a large [necropolis](/wiki/Necropolis "Necropolis") under *[Praça da Figueira](/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_da_Figueira "Praça da Figueira")* ; a large forum and other buildings such as [insulae](/wiki/Insula_(building) "Insula (building)") (multi-storied apartment buildings) in the area between Castle Hill and the historic city core. Many of these ruins were first unearthed during the mid-18th century (when the recent discovery of [Pompeii](/wiki/Pompeii "Pompeii") made Roman archaeology fashionable among Europe's upper classes).

The city prospered as [piracy](/wiki/Piracy "Piracy") was eliminated and technological advances were introduced, consequently *Felicitas Julia* became a center of trade with the Roman provinces of [Britannia](/wiki/Roman_Britain "Roman Britain") (particularly [Cornwall](/wiki/Cornwall "Cornwall")) and the [Rhine](/wiki/Rhine "Rhine"). Economically strong, Olissipo was known for its [garum](/wiki/Garum "Garum") (a fish sauce highly prized by the elites of the empire and exported in [amphorae](/wiki/Amphora "Amphora") to Rome), wine, salt, and horse-breeding, while Roman culture permeated the hinterland. The city was connected by a broad road to Western Hispania's two other large cities, [Bracara Augusta](/wiki/Bracara_Augusta "Bracara Augusta") in the province of [Tarraconensis](/wiki/Tarraconensis "Tarraconensis") (Portuguese [Braga](/wiki/Braga "Braga")), and [Emerita Augusta](/wiki/Emerita_Augusta "Emerita Augusta"), the capital of [Lusitania](/wiki/Lusitania "Lusitania"). The city was ruled by an [oligarchical](/wiki/Oligarchy "Oligarchy") council dominated by two families, the Julii and the Cassiae, although regional authority was administered by the Roman Governor of Emerita or directly by Emperor [Tiberius](/wiki/Tiberius "Tiberius"). Among the majority of [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") speakers lived a large minority of Greek traders and slaves.

Olissipo, like most great cities in the Western Empire, was a center for the dissemination of Christianity. Its first attested [Bishop](/wiki/Patriarch_of_Lisbon "Patriarch of Lisbon") was Potamius (c. 356), and there were several [martyrs](/wiki/Martyr "Martyr") during the period of persecution of the Christians: [Verissimus, Maxima, and Julia](/wiki/Holy_Martyrs_of_Lisbon "Holy Martyrs of Lisbon") are the most significant examples. By the time of the [Fall of Rome](/wiki/Fall_of_Rome "Fall of Rome"), Olissipo had become a notable Christian center.

[São Jorge Castle](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle "São Jorge Castle") and the surrounding neighborhoods of [Castelo](/wiki/Castelo_(Lisbon) "Castelo (Lisbon)"), Mouraria, and [Alfama](/wiki/Alfama "Alfama")  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]

Following the disintegration of the Western Roman Empire, there were [barbarian](/wiki/Barbarian "Barbarian") invasions; between 409 and 429 the city was occupied successively by [Sarmatians](/wiki/Sarmatian "Sarmatian"), [Alans](/wiki/Alans "Alans") and [Vandals](/wiki/Vandals "Vandals"). The Germanic [Suebi](/wiki/Suebi "Suebi"), who established a kingdom in [Gallaecia](/wiki/Gallaecia "Gallaecia") (modern [Galicia](/wiki/Galicia_(Spain) "Galicia (Spain)") and northern Portugal), with its capital in *[Bracara Augusta](/wiki/Bracara_Augusta "Bracara Augusta")* , also controlled the region of Lisbon until 585. In 585, the Suebi Kingdom was integrated into the Germanic [Visigothic](/wiki/Visigoths "Visigoths") Kingdom of Toledo, which comprised all of the Iberian Peninsula: Lisbon was then called *Ulishbona*.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Siege_of_Lisbon_-_Muslim_surrender.jpg/220px-Siege_of_Lisbon_-_Muslim_surrender.jpg)](/wiki/File:Siege_of_Lisbon_-_Muslim_surrender.jpg) King [Afonso Henriques](/wiki/Afonso_Henriques "Afonso Henriques") reconquered the city from the [Almoravid Empire](/wiki/Almoravid_dynasty "Almoravid dynasty") at the 1147 [siege of Lisbon](/wiki/Siege_of_Lisbon "Siege of Lisbon").

On 6 August 711, Lisbon was taken by the [Muslim](/wiki/Moors "Moors") forces of the [Umayyad Caliphate](/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate "Umayyad Caliphate"). These conquerors built many mosques and houses, rebuilt the city wall (known as the *Cerca Moura* ) and established administrative control, while permitting the diverse population of [Muwallads](/wiki/Muwallad "Muwallad"), [Arabs](/wiki/Arabs "Arabs"), [Berbers](/wiki/Berbers "Berbers"), [Mozarabs](/wiki/Mozarabs "Mozarabs"), *[Saqaliba](/wiki/Saqaliba "Saqaliba")* , and [Jews](/wiki/Jews "Jews") to maintain their socio-cultural lifestyles. [Mozarabic](/wiki/Andalusi_Romance "Andalusi Romance") was the native language spoken by most of the Christian population although Arabic was widely known as spoken by all religious communities. Islam was the official religion practised by the Arabs, Berbers, Saqaliba and Muwallad.

The ancient Muslim influence is still visible in the [Alfama](/wiki/Alfama "Alfama") district, an old quarter of Lisbon that survived the [1755 Lisbon earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake "1755 Lisbon earthquake"): many place-names are derived from Arabic and the Alfama (the oldest existing district of Lisbon) was derived from the Arabic "*al-hamma* ".

For a brief time, Lisbon was an independent Muslim kingdom known as the [Taifa of Lisbon](/wiki/Taifa_of_Lisbon "Taifa of Lisbon") (1022--1094), before being conquered by the larger [Taifa of Badajoz](/wiki/Taifa_of_Badajoz "Taifa of Badajoz").

In 1108 Lisbon was raided and occupied by [Norwegian](/wiki/Norway "Norway") crusaders led by [Sigurd I](/wiki/Sigurd_I_of_Norway "Sigurd I of Norway") on their way to the [Holy Land](/wiki/Holy_Land "Holy Land") as part of the [Norwegian Crusade](/wiki/Norwegian_Crusade "Norwegian Crusade") and occupied by crusader forces for three years.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^ It was taken by the Moorish [Almoravids](/wiki/Almoravids "Almoravids") in 1111.{#cite_ref-41}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Siege_of_Lisbon_1384.JPG/220px-Siege_of_Lisbon_1384.JPG)](/wiki/File:Siege_of_Lisbon_1384.JPG) The [1384 siege of Lisbon](/wiki/Siege_of_Lisbon_(1384) "Siege of Lisbon (1384)") in [Froissart's Chronicles](/wiki/Froissart%27s_Chronicles "Froissart's Chronicles")

In 1147, as part of [Portuguese efforts during the *Reconquista*](/wiki/Portugal_in_the_Reconquista "Portugal in the Reconquista"), [Afonso I of Portugal](/wiki/Afonso_I_of_Portugal "Afonso I of Portugal") [besieged and reconquered Lisbon](/wiki/Siege_of_Lisbon "Siege of Lisbon") with the aid of crusader knights. The city, with around 154,000 residents at the time, was returned to Christian rule. The reconquest of Portugal and re-establishment of [Christianity](/wiki/Christianity "Christianity") is one of the most significant events in Lisbon's history, described in the chronicle *[Expugnatione Lyxbonensi](/wiki/Expugnatione_Lyxbonensi "Expugnatione Lyxbonensi")* , which describes, among other incidents, how the local bishop was killed by the crusaders and the city's residents prayed to the [Virgin Mary](/wiki/Virgin_Mary "Virgin Mary") as it happened. Some of the Muslim residents converted to Roman Catholicism and most of those who did not convert fled to other parts of the Islamic world, primarily [Muslim Spain](/wiki/Muslim_Spain "Muslim Spain") and [North Africa](/wiki/North_Africa "North Africa"). All mosques were either destroyed or altered and converted into churches. As a result of the end of Muslim rule in the mid-12th century, spoken Arabic quickly lost its place in Lisbon, and disappeared altogether.

With its central location, Lisbon became the capital city of the new Portuguese territory in 1255. The first Portuguese university was founded in Lisbon in 1290 by King [Denis I](/wiki/Dinis_I_of_Portugal "Dinis I of Portugal"); for many years the *[Studium Generale](/wiki/Studium_Generale "Studium Generale")* (*General Study* ) was transferred intermittently to [Coimbra](/wiki/Coimbra "Coimbra"), where it was installed permanently in the 16th century as the [University of Coimbra](/wiki/University_of_Coimbra "University of Coimbra").

In 1384, the city was besieged by King [Juan I of Castille](/wiki/Juan_I_of_Castille "Juan I of Castille"), as a part of the ongoing [1383--1385 Crisis](/wiki/1383%E2%80%931385_Crisis "1383–1385 Crisis"). The result of the siege was a victory for the Portuguese led by [Nuno Álvares Pereira](/wiki/Nuno_%C3%81lvares_Pereira "Nuno Álvares Pereira").

During the last centuries of the Middle Ages, Lisbon expanded substantially and became an important trading post with both [Northern European](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe") and Mediterranean cities.  

### Early Modern {#Early_Modern}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Early Modern")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Lisboa_1500-1510.jpg/220px-Lisboa_1500-1510.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisboa_1500-1510.jpg) The oldest known panorama of Lisbon (1500--1510) from the *Crónica de Dom Afonso Henriques* by [Duarte Galvão](/wiki/Duarte_Galv%C3%A3o "Duarte Galvão")

When the Spaniards expelled the Jews from Spanish territory, many of them fled to Lisbon. Although acknowledging the central importance of the Jews to the city's prosperity, [Manuel I](/wiki/Manuel_I_of_Portugal "Manuel I of Portugal") decreed in 1497 that all Jews must convert to Christianity, only those who refused being forced to leave, but not before the expropriation of their property.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-Roitman2011-42)^ In 1506, an anti-semitic movement among the [Old Christians](/wiki/Old_Christians "Old Christians") of Lisbon culminated in a [massacre](/wiki/Lisbon_massacre "Lisbon massacre") lasting four days in which some 1,000 to 4,000 [New Christian](/wiki/New_Christian "New Christian") men, women and children, converted descendants of [Sephardic Jews](/wiki/Sephardic_Jews "Sephardic Jews"), are estimated to have been killed.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-Soyer2007-43)^ The king was at Évora when these events occurred, but angered when he received the news, he ordered an investigation which resulted in two of the instigating friars being excommunicated and burned alive.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-PintoMateus2014-44)^{#cite_ref-PintoMateus2014_44-0}

Most of the Portuguese expeditions of the [Age of Discovery](/wiki/Age_of_Discovery "Age of Discovery") set out from Lisbon during the period from the end of the 15th century to the beginning of the 17th century, including [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama")'s expedition to [India](/wiki/India "India") in 1498. The following years of the 16th century began Lisbon's golden era: the city was the European hub of commerce between [Africa](/wiki/History_of_Portugal_(1415%E2%80%931578) "History of Portugal (1415–1578)"), [India](/wiki/Portuguese_India "Portuguese India"), the [Far East](/wiki/Nanban_trade "Nanban trade") and later, [Brazil](/wiki/Colonial_Brazil "Colonial Brazil"), and acquired great riches by exploiting the trade in spices, slaves, sugar, textiles and other goods. This period saw the rise of the exuberant [Manueline](/wiki/Manueline "Manueline") style in architecture, which left its mark in many 16th-century monuments (including Lisbon's [Belém Tower](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower "Belém Tower") and [Jerónimos Monastery](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery "Jerónimos Monastery"), which were declared [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites "UNESCO World Heritage Sites")). A description of Lisbon in the 16th century was written by [Damião de Góis](/wiki/Dami%C3%A3o_de_G%C3%B3is "Damião de Góis") and published in 1554.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Vista_dos_Jeronomis_por_Filipe_Lobo_%282%29.jpg/220px-Vista_dos_Jeronomis_por_Filipe_Lobo_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vista_dos_Jeronomis_por_Filipe_Lobo_(2).jpg) [King Manuel I](/wiki/Manuel_I_of_Portugal "Manuel I of Portugal") ordered [Jerónimos Monastery](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery "Jerónimos Monastery") to be built in [Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_(Lisbon) "Belém (Lisbon)"), to serve [Portuguese discoverers](/wiki/Portuguese_discoveries "Portuguese discoveries"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Terreiro_do_Pa%C3%A7o_em_1662.jpg/220px-Terreiro_do_Pa%C3%A7o_em_1662.jpg)](/wiki/File:Terreiro_do_Pa%C3%A7o_em_1662.jpg) [Ribeira Palace](/wiki/Ribeira_Palace "Ribeira Palace") and the [Terreiro do Paço](/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio "Praça do Comércio") depicted in 1662 by [Dirk Stoop](/wiki/Dirk_Stoop "Dirk Stoop")

The [succession crisis](/wiki/Iberian_Union "Iberian Union") of 1580, initiated a sixty-year period of dual monarchy in Portugal and Spain under the [Spanish Habsburgs](/wiki/Habsburg_Spain "Habsburg Spain").^[\[46\]](#cite_note-46)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)^ This is referred to as the "Philippine Dominion" (*Domínio Filipino* ), since all [three Spanish kings](/wiki/Philippine_Dynasty "Philippine Dynasty") during that period were called Philip (*Filipe* ). In 1589, Lisbon was the target of an incursion by the [English Armada](/wiki/English_Armada "English Armada") led by [Francis Drake](/wiki/Francis_Drake "Francis Drake"), while [Queen Elizabeth](/wiki/Elizabeth_I "Elizabeth I") supported a Portuguese [pretender](/wiki/Pretender "Pretender") in [Antonio, Prior of Crato](/wiki/Antonio,_Prior_of_Crato "Antonio, Prior of Crato"), but support for Crato was lacking and the expedition was a failure. The [Portuguese Restoration War](/wiki/Portuguese_Restoration_War "Portuguese Restoration War"), which began with a [coup d'état](/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "Coup d'état") organised by the nobility and [bourgeoisie](/wiki/Bourgeois "Bourgeois") in Lisbon and executed on 1 December 1640, restored Portuguese independence. The period from 1640 to 1668 was marked by periodic skirmishes between Portugal and Spain, as well as short episodes of more serious warfare until the [Treaty of Lisbon](/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon_(1668) "Treaty of Lisbon (1668)") was signed in 1668.{#cite_ref-47}

In the early 18th century, gold from Brazil allowed [King John V](/wiki/John_V_of_Portugal "John V of Portugal") to sponsor the building of several [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") churches and theatres in the city. Prior to the 18th century, Lisbon had experienced several significant earthquakes -- eight in the 14th century, five in the 16th century (including the [1531 earthquake](/wiki/1531_Lisbon_earthquake "1531 Lisbon earthquake") that destroyed 1,500 houses and the 1597 earthquake in which three streets vanished), and three in the 17th century.

On 1 November 1755, the city was destroyed by another [devastating earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake "1755 Lisbon earthquake"), which killed an estimated 30,000 to 40,000 Lisbon residents^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^ of a population estimated at between 200,000 and 275,000,^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^^[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)^ and destroyed 85 percent of the city's structures.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)^ Among several important buildings of the city, the [Ribeira Palace](/wiki/Ribeira_Palace "Ribeira Palace") and the [Hospital Real de Todos os Santos](/wiki/Hospital_Real_de_Todos_os_Santos "Hospital Real de Todos os Santos") were lost. In coastal areas, such as [Peniche](/wiki/Peniche_Municipality "Peniche Municipality"), situated about 80 km (50 mi) north of Lisbon, many people were killed by the following [tsunami](/wiki/Tsunami "Tsunami").{#cite_ref-51}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/142px-Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png)](/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_Pra%C3%A7a_da_Patriarcal_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png/142px-Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas%2C_1757.png)](/wiki/File:Ruinas_da_Igreja_de_S._Nicolau_ap%C3%B3s_o_Terramoto_de_1755_-_Jacques_Philippe_Le_Bas,_1757.png)  
The [1755 Lisbon earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake "1755 Lisbon earthquake") devastated Lisbon with an estimated magnitude between 8.5 and 9.0.

By 1755, Lisbon was one of the largest cities in Europe; the catastrophic event shocked the whole of Europe and left a deep impression on its collective psyche. [Voltaire](/wiki/Voltaire "Voltaire") wrote a long poem, *Poême sur le désastre de Lisbonne* , shortly after the quake, and mentioned it in his 1759 novel *[Candide](/wiki/Candide "Candide")* (indeed, many argue that this critique of [optimism](/wiki/Optimism "Optimism") was inspired by that earthquake). [Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr.](/wiki/Oliver_Wendell_Holmes_Sr. "Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr.") also mentions it in his 1857 poem, *The Deacon's Masterpiece, or The Wonderful One-Hoss Shay*.

After the 1755 earthquake, the city was rebuilt largely according to the plans of Prime Minister [Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo](/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A3o_Jos%C3%A9_de_Carvalho_e_Melo "Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo"), the [1st Marquis of Pombal](/wiki/Marquis_of_Pombal "Marquis of Pombal"); the lower town began to be known as the *Baixa Pombalina* ([Pombaline central district](/wiki/Pombaline_Lower_Town "Pombaline Lower Town")). Instead of rebuilding the medieval town, Pombal decided to demolish what remained after the earthquake and rebuild the city centre in accordance with principles of modern urban design. It was reconstructed in an open rectangular plan with two great squares: the *[Praça do Rossio](/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_do_Rossio "Praça do Rossio")* and the *[Praça do Comércio](/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio "Praça do Comércio")* . The first, the central commercial district, is the traditional gathering place of the city and the location of the older cafés, theatres and restaurants; the second became the city's main access to the River Tagus and point of departure and arrival for seagoing vessels, adorned by a triumphal arch (1873) and a monument to King [Joseph I](/wiki/Joseph_I_of_Portugal "Joseph I of Portugal").  

### Modern era {#Modern_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Modern era")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg/220px-Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Proclama%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Rep%C3%BAblica_Portuguesa.jpg) The [Proclamation of the Portuguese Republic](/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution "5 October 1910 revolution") in 1910

In the first years of the 19th century, Portugal was invaded by the troops of [Napoléon Bonaparte](/wiki/Napol%C3%A9on_Bonaparte "Napoléon Bonaparte"), forcing Queen [Maria I](/wiki/Maria_I_of_Portugal "Maria I of Portugal") and Prince-Regent [John](/wiki/John_VI_of_Portugal "John VI of Portugal") (future John VI) to flee temporarily to Brazil. By the time the new King returned to Lisbon, many of the buildings and properties were pillaged, sacked or destroyed by the invaders.

During the 19th century, the Liberal movement introduced new changes into the urban landscape. The principal areas were in the *Baixa* and along the *Chiado* district, where shops, tobacconists shops, cafés, bookstores, clubs and theatres proliferated. The development of industry and commerce determined the growth of the city, seeing the transformation of the [Passeio Público](/wiki/Passeio_P%C3%BAblico_(Lisbon) "Passeio Público (Lisbon)"), a Pombaline era park, into the [Avenida da Liberdade](/wiki/Avenida_da_Liberdade "Avenida da Liberdade"), as the city grew farther from the Tagus.

Lisbon was the site of the [regicide](/wiki/Lisbon_Regicide "Lisbon Regicide") of [Carlos I of Portugal](/wiki/Carlos_I_of_Portugal "Carlos I of Portugal") in 1908, an event which culminated two years later in the establishment of the First Republic.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Lisbon%2C_the_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_da_Ajuda.JPG/220px-Lisbon%2C_the_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_da_Ajuda.JPG)](/wiki/File:Lisbon,_the_Pal%C3%A1cio_Nacional_da_Ajuda.JPG) The [Palace of Ajuda](/wiki/Palace_of_Ajuda "Palace of Ajuda") was built as a residence for the [King of Portugal](/wiki/King_of_Portugal "King of Portugal") following the [1755 Lisbon Earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_Earthquake "1755 Lisbon Earthquake"). [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Teatro_Dona_Maria_II_%282.%C2%AA_metade_do_s%C3%A9c._XIX%29_%28cropped%29.png/220px-Teatro_Dona_Maria_II_%282.%C2%AA_metade_do_s%C3%A9c._XIX%29_%28cropped%29.png)](/wiki/File:Teatro_Dona_Maria_II_(2.%C2%AA_metade_do_s%C3%A9c._XIX)_(cropped).png) [Queen Maria II National Theatre](/wiki/D._Maria_II_National_Theatre "D. Maria II National Theatre") was built in 1842.

The city refounded its university in 1911 after centuries of inactivity in Lisbon, incorporating reformed former colleges and other non-university higher education schools of the city (such as the *Escola Politécnica* -- now *Faculdade de Ciências* ). Today there are two public universities in the city ([University of Lisbon](/wiki/University_of_Lisbon "University of Lisbon") and [New University of Lisbon](/wiki/New_University_of_Lisbon "New University of Lisbon")), a public university institute ([ISCTE - Lisbon University Institute](/wiki/ISCTE_-_Lisbon_University_Institute "ISCTE - Lisbon University Institute")) and a [polytechnic](/wiki/Polytechnic_(Portugal) "Polytechnic (Portugal)") institute (IPL -- [Instituto Politécnico de Lisboa](/wiki/Instituto_Polit%C3%A9cnico_de_Lisboa "Instituto Politécnico de Lisboa")).

During [World War II](/wiki/Portugal_in_World_War_II "Portugal in World War II"), Lisbon was one of the very few neutral, open European Atlantic ports, a major gateway for refugees to the U.S. and a haven for spies. More than 100,000 refugees were able to flee [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") via Lisbon.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-52)^{#cite_ref-52}

During the [Estado Novo](/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal) "Estado Novo (Portugal)") regime (1926--1974), Lisbon, under the influence of [Duarte Pacheco](/wiki/Duarte_Pacheco "Duarte Pacheco"), the minister of works, was expanded at the cost of other districts within the country, resulting in nationalist and monumental projects. New residential and public developments were constructed; the zone of [Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_(Lisbon) "Belém (Lisbon)") was modified for the [1940 Portuguese Exhibition](/wiki/Portuguese_World_Exhibition "Portuguese World Exhibition"), while along the periphery new districts appeared to house the growing population. The inauguration of the bridge over the Tagus allowed a rapid connection between both sides of the river.

Lisbon was the site of three revolutions in the 20th century. The first, the [5 October 1910 revolution](/wiki/5_October_1910_revolution "5 October 1910 revolution"), brought an end to the [Portuguese monarchy](/wiki/Portuguese_monarchy "Portuguese monarchy") and established the highly unstable and corrupt [Portuguese First Republic](/wiki/Portuguese_First_Republic "Portuguese First Republic"). The [6 June 1926 revolution](/wiki/28_May_1926_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "28 May 1926 coup d'état") ended the first republic and firmly established the [Estado Novo](/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal) "Estado Novo (Portugal)"), or the [Portuguese Second Republic](/wiki/Portuguese_Second_Republic "Portuguese Second Republic"), as the ruling regime.  

### Contemporary {#Contemporary}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Contemporary")\]

The [Carnation Revolution](/wiki/Carnation_Revolution "Carnation Revolution"), which took place on 25 April 1974, ended the right-wing [Estado Novo](/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal) "Estado Novo (Portugal)") regime and reformed the country to become as it is today, the [Portuguese Third Republic](/wiki/Portuguese_Third_Republic "Portuguese Third Republic").

In the 1990s, many of the districts were renovated and projects in the historic quarters were established to modernise those areas, for instance, architectural and patrimonial buildings were renovated, the northern margin of the Tagus was re-purposed for leisure and residential use, the [Vasco da Gama Bridge](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge "Vasco da Gama Bridge") was constructed and the eastern part of the municipality was re-purposed for [Expo '98](/wiki/Expo_%2798 "Expo '98") to commemorate the 500th anniversary of [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama")'s sea voyage to India, a voyage that would bring immense riches to Lisbon and cause many of Lisbon's landmarks to be built.

In 1988, a fire in the historical district of [Chiado](/wiki/Chiado "Chiado") saw the destruction of many 18th-century [Pombaline style](/wiki/Pombaline_style "Pombaline style") buildings. A series of restoration works has brought the area back to its former self and made it a high-scale shopping district.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%2808%29_edited.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%2808%29_edited.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(08)_edited.jpg) The [Treaty of Lisbon](/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon "Treaty of Lisbon"), which forms the constitutional basis of the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), was signed at the [Jerónimos Monastery](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery "Jerónimos Monastery") in 2007.

The [Lisbon Agenda](/wiki/Lisbon_Agenda "Lisbon Agenda") was a European Union agreement on measures to revitalise the EU economy, signed in Lisbon in March 2000. In October 2007 Lisbon hosted the [2007 EU Summit](/wiki/2007_EU_Summit "2007 EU Summit"), where an agreement was reached regarding a new EU governance model. The resulting [Treaty of Lisbon](/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon "Treaty of Lisbon") was signed on 13 December 2007 and came into force on 1 December 2009.

Lisbon has been the site for many international events and programmes. In 1994, Lisbon was the [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture"). On 3 November 2005, Lisbon hosted the [MTV European Music Awards](/wiki/MTV_Europe_Music_Awards_2005 "MTV Europe Music Awards 2005"). On 7 July 2007, Lisbon held the ceremony of the "New 7 Wonders Of The World"^[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)^ election, in the [Luz Stadium](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_da_Luz "Estádio da Luz"), with live transmission for millions of people all over the world. Every two years, Lisbon hosts the [Rock in Rio Lisboa](/wiki/Rock_in_Rio#Lisboa,_Portugal,_and_Madrid,_Spain "Rock in Rio") Music Festival, one of the largest in the world. Lisbon hosted the [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") summit (19--20 November 2010), a [summit meeting](/wiki/Summit_(meeting) "Summit (meeting)") that is regarded as a periodic opportunity for Heads of State and [Heads of Government](/wiki/Head_of_Government "Head of Government") of [NATO member states](/wiki/NATO_member_states "NATO member states") to evaluate and provide strategic direction for Alliance activities.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-54)^ The city hosts the [Web Summit](/wiki/Web_Summit "Web Summit") and is the head office for the [Group of Seven Plus (G7+)](/wiki/G7%2B "G7+"). In 2018 it hosted the [Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2018 "Eurovision Song Contest 2018") for the first time as well as the [Michelin Gala](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide").^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^ On 11 July 2018, the [Aga Khan](/wiki/Aga_Khan_IV "Aga Khan IV") officially chose the Henrique de Mendonça Palace, located on Rua Marquês de Fronteira, as the *[Divan](/wiki/Divan "Divan")* , or seat, of the global [Nizari Muslim](/wiki/Nizari_Isma%27ilism "Nizari Isma'ilism") [Imamate](/wiki/Imamate "Imamate").^[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)^^[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)^ Lisbon hosted [World Youth Day 2023](/wiki/World_Youth_Day_2023 "World Youth Day 2023") in August of that year, attracting [Catholic](/wiki/Catholicism "Catholicism") youth from the around the world. [Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis") led several events, with the final [mass](/wiki/Mass_(liturgy) "Mass (liturgy)") held in the city's Parque do Tejo having an estimated 1.5 million attendees.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)^^[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

### Physical geography {#Physical_geography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Physical geography")\]

Lisbon is located at [38°42′49.75″N 9°8′21.79″W﻿ / ﻿38.7138194°N 9.1393861°W﻿ / 38.7138194; -9.1393861](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Lisbon&params=38_42_49.75_N_9_8_21.79_W_type:city(2042326)_region:PT), situated at the mouth of the [Tagus River](/wiki/Tagus_River "Tagus River") and is the westernmost capital of a mainland European country. The river delta is [inverted](/wiki/Inverted_river_delta "Inverted river delta").

The westernmost part of Lisbon is occupied by the [Monsanto Forest Park](/wiki/Monsanto_Forest_Park "Monsanto Forest Park"), a 10 km^2^ (4 sq mi) urban park, one of the largest in Europe, and occupying 10% of the municipality.

The city occupies an area of 100.05 km^2^ (39 sq mi), and its city boundaries, unlike those of most major cities, coincide with those of the municipality.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)^ The rest of the urbanised area of the Lisbon urban area, known generically as [Greater Lisbon](/wiki/Grande_Lisboa_Subregion "Grande Lisboa Subregion") ([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Grande Lisboa* ) includes several administratively defined cities and municipalities, in the north bank of the Tagus River. The larger [Lisbon metropolitan area](/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area "Lisbon metropolitan area") includes the [Setúbal Peninsula](/wiki/Pen%C3%ADnsula_de_Set%C3%BAbal "Península de Setúbal") to the south.{#cite_ref-61}  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Climate")\]  
Main article: [Climate of Lisbon](/wiki/Climate_of_Lisbon "Climate of Lisbon")

Lisbon has a [Mediterranean climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Csa* )^[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)^ with mild, rainy winters and warm to hot, dry summers. The average annual temperature is 17.4 °C (63.3 °F), 21.3 °C (70.3 °F) during the day and 13.5 °C (56.3 °F) at night.{#cite_ref-62}

In the coldest month -- January -- the highest temperature during the day typically ranges from 11 to 19 °C (52 to 66 °F), the lowest temperature at night ranges from 3 to 13 °C (37 to 55 °F) and the average sea temperature is 16 °C (61 °F).^[\[63\]](#cite_note-seatemperature-63)^ In the warmest month -- August -- the highest temperature during the day typically ranges from 25 to 32 °C (77 to 90 °F), the lowest temperature at night ranges from 14 to 20 °C (57 to 68 °F) and the average sea temperature is around 20 °C (68 °F).^[\[63\]](#cite_note-seatemperature-63)^{#cite_ref-seatemperature_63-1}

Among European capitals, Lisbon ranks among those with the warmest winters and has the mildest winter nights out of any major European city, with a minimum mean of 8.2 °C (46.8 °F) in the coldest month. The coldest temperature ever recorded in Lisbon was −1.2 °C (30 °F) in February 1956; although other locations in its [metropolitan area](/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area "Lisbon metropolitan area") can record lower temperatures, not being as affected by the [urban heat island](/wiki/Urban_heat_island "Urban heat island") of the city centre, with [Sintra](/wiki/Sintra "Sintra") and [Setúbal](/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal "Setúbal") having reached −4 °C (25 °F) and −5.1 °C (23 °F) respectively, both experiencing about 13 days of frost per year on average.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)^ The highest temperature ever recorded in Lisbon was 44.0 °C (111.2 °F) on 4 August 2018.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}

The city has around 2,806 hours of sunshine per year, averaging 4.6 hours of sunshine per day in December and 11.4 hours of sunshine per day in July, though when disregarding the duration of the day August is actually the sunniest, with over 80% chance of direct sunlight hitting the ground.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-67)^{#cite_ref-67}

Lisbon has around 750 mm (30 in) of precipitation per year. November and December are the wettest months, accounting for a third of the total annual precipitation. July and August are the driest.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-IPMA-68)^{#cite_ref-IPMA_68-0}

### Neighborhoods {#Neighborhoods}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Neighborhoods")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Lisboa-lisbon-_panorama.jpg/940px-Lisboa-lisbon-_panorama.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisboa-lisbon-_panorama.jpg "View of Lisbon's waterfront districts from the Christ the King viewpoint.")  
[](/wiki/File:Lisboa-lisbon-_panorama.jpg "File:Lisboa-lisbon- panorama.jpg")
View of Lisbon's waterfront districts from the [Christ the King](/wiki/Christ_the_King_(Almada) "Christ the King (Almada)") viewpoint.

Locally, Lisbon's inhabitants may commonly refer to the spaces of Lisbon in terms of historic *Bairros de Lisboa* ([neighbourhoods](/wiki/Bairro "Bairro")). These communities have no clearly defined boundaries and represent distinctive quarters of the city that have in common a historical culture, similar living standards, and identifiable architectural landmarks, as exemplified by the *Bairro Alto* , *Alfama* , *Chiado*, and so forth.  

#### Alcântara {#Alc.C3.A2ntara}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Alcântara")\]  
Main article: [Alcântara](/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara,_Lisbon "Alcântara, Lisbon")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Capela_de_Santo_Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_%2837047725223%29.jpg/220px-Capela_de_Santo_Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_%2837047725223%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Capela_de_Santo_Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_(37047725223).jpg) Santo Amaro, Alcântara [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Alc%C3%A2ntara_by_wax115.jpg/220px-Alc%C3%A2ntara_by_wax115.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alc%C3%A2ntara_by_wax115.jpg) [Alcântara](/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara_(Lisbon) "Alcântara (Lisbon)") from the [Port of Lisbon](/wiki/Port_of_Lisbon "Port of Lisbon") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Doca_de_Sto._Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_%282449827584%29.jpg/220px-Doca_de_Sto._Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_%282449827584%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Doca_de_Sto._Amaro_-_Lisboa_-_Portugal_(2449827584).jpg) Lisbon "docas"

Alcântara is situated along the northern bank of the Tagus River, between the parishes of Belém to the west and Estrela to the east. Its proximity to both the city centre and the riverside makes it a well-connected and popular area for both locals and tourists. Although today it is quite central, it was once a mere suburb of Lisbon, comprising mostly farms and country estates of the nobility with their palaces. Amongst the palaces found in the neighbourhood the most notable are:

* Palácio da Ega (16th century), now hosting the [Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino](/wiki/Arquivo_Hist%C3%B3rico_Ultramarino "Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino")^[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}
* Palácio Condes da Ribeira Grande (18th century), now hosting the MACAM museum and an hotel^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}
* Palácio Burnay (18th century), now in the process of being restored so as to house a state-owned enterprise focused on culture^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}
* Palacete do Conde de Burnay (19th century), now housing a public library (biblioteca de Alcântara)^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^{#cite_ref-75}
* Palácio Vale-Flor (20th century), nowadays a restaurant and an hotel^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^{#cite_ref-76}

In the 16th century, there was a brook there which the nobles used to promenade in their boats.

During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Alcântara became a popular industrial area, with many small factories and warehouses and docks along the waterfront. The presence of these industries attracted many working-class families.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/DF1_9862_%2845046589254%29.jpg/220px-DF1_9862_%2845046589254%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:DF1_9862_(45046589254).jpg) Lx Factory in Alcântara [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Pal%C3%A1cio_Burnay_7718.jpg/220px-Pal%C3%A1cio_Burnay_7718.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pal%C3%A1cio_Burnay_7718.jpg) Palácio Burnay, Alcântara

By the mid-20th century, the area had experienced some decline as industries closed down. However, since the late 20th century, Alcântara has seen revitalisation, with many of the old factories repurposed into trendy spaces such as art galleries, nightclubs, and creative hubs. In the early 1990s, Alcântara began to attract youth because of the number of pubs and discothèques. This was mainly due to its outer area of mostly commercial buildings, which acted as barriers to the noise-generating nightlife (which acted as a buffer to the residential communities surrounding it). In the meantime, some of these areas began to become gentrified, attracting loft developments and new flats, which have profited from its river views and central location.

Alcântara has emerged as one of Lisbon's most dynamic areas for nightlife and culture. The riverfront of Alcântara is known for its nightclubs and bars. The area is commonly known as *docas* (docks), since most of the clubs and bars are housed in converted dock warehouses.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}

Key places of interest/cultural landmarks in the neighbourhood include:

* **LX Factory** : A cultural and creative complex housed in a former industrial site now home to cafes, restaurants, co-working spaces, shops, and art installations. LX Factory frequently hosts markets, exhibitions, and live performances^[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}
* **Village Underground** : An innovative cultural space made of recycled shipping containers and old buses, used as offices, restaurants, and even a stage for performances. It exemplifies the creative reuse of industrial spaces in Alcântara.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-80)^{#cite_ref-80}
* **Museums** : Many museums can be found in Alcantara, including the "Museu de Macau" (Macau Museum),^[\[81\]](#cite_note-81)^ "Museu da Carris" (Carris - Public transportation museum),^[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)^ the "B-Mad museum" (Berardo - Museum Art Deco)^[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)^ and the set-to-open in 2024 MACAM (Armando Martins **Museum** of Contemporary Art)^[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}
* **Pilar 7** : situated within one of the massive support pillars of the 25 de Abril Bridge. It was created to offer visitors a closer look at the bridge's architectural and engineering marvel, providing access to areas of the bridge that would otherwise be off-limits. The main focus is on the structural aspects and construction of the bridge, but it also incorporates interactive exhibits and a viewpoint.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}

The neighbourhood is also noticeable for hosting the "Lisbon Congress Centre" (Centro de congressos de Lisboa),^[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)^^[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)^ the Lisbon Metropolitan Orchestra (Orquestra Metropolitana de Lisboa)^[\[88\]](#cite_note-88)^^[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)^ and the [Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino](/wiki/Arquivo_Hist%C3%B3rico_Ultramarino "Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino").^[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)^{#cite_ref-90}  

#### Alfama {#Alfama}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Alfama")\]  
Main article: [Alfama](/wiki/Alfama "Alfama")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/A_ver_S._Vicente.jpg/220px-A_ver_S._Vicente.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_ver_S._Vicente.jpg) [Alfama](/wiki/Alfama "Alfama"), with the churches of [S. Vicente de Fora](/wiki/Monastery_of_S%C3%A3o_Vicente_de_Fora "Monastery of São Vicente de Fora"), [S. Engrácia](/wiki/Church_of_Santa_Engr%C3%A1cia "Church of Santa Engrácia"), and [S. Estêvão](/wiki/Igreja_de_Santo_Est%C3%AAv%C3%A3o_(Lisbon) "Igreja de Santo Estêvão (Lisbon)"), and the Tagus river behind

Alfama, the oldest district of Lisbon, spreads down the southern slope from the [Castle of São Jorge](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle "São Jorge Castle") to the [River Tagus](/wiki/River_Tagus "River Tagus"). Its name, derived from the [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") *Al-hamma* , means fountains or baths. During the [Islamic invasion of Iberia](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Iberian_Peninsula "Muslim conquest of the Iberian Peninsula"), the Alfama constituted the largest part of the city, extending west to the [Baixa](/wiki/Baixa "Baixa") neighbourhood. Increasingly, the Alfama became inhabited by fishermen and the poor: its fame as a poor neighbourhood continues to this day. Many of the buildings date back to the 18th century, showcasing traditional Portuguese architecture, complete with colorful tiled facades and wrought-iron balconies. While the [1755 Lisbon earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake "1755 Lisbon earthquake") caused considerable damage throughout the capital, the Alfama was largely spared and survived with little damage, thanks to its compact labyrinth of narrow streets and small squares.

This historic district has retained much of its original character. It is a historical quarter of mixed-use buildings occupied by [Fado](/wiki/Fado "Fado") bars, restaurants, and homes with small shops downstairs. Fado, the typically Portuguese style of melancholy music, is common (but not obligatory) in the restaurants of the district.

Modernising trends have invigorated the district: old houses have been re-purposed or remodelled, while new buildings have been constructed.

Alfama hosts several events throughout the year, including the popular **Festas de Santo António**, where locals celebrate with street parties, music, and food. This vibrant atmosphere showcases the community's spirit and connection to its cultural roots.

Key places of interest/cultural landmarks in the neighbourhood include:

* **São Jorge Castle** : historic [castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") which has been continuously occupied for the last 3,000 years^[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}
* **Miradouros**: Amongst the most emblematic viewpoints there are Miradouro de Santa Luzia (where the Igreja de Santa Luzia e de São Brás stands) and the Miradouro das Portas do Sol.
* **Museums** : Many museums can be found in Alfama, including the "Museu de Santo António" (Saint Anthony Museum),^[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)^ "Museu do Aljube - Resistência e Liberdade" (Aljube - Estado Novo dictatorship museum),^[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)^ the "Museu do Teatro Romano" (Roman Theatre Museum),^[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)^ the "Fundação José Saramago" (José Saramago Foundation)^[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)^ and the "Museu de Artes Decorativas Portuguesas" (Museum of Portuguese Decorative Arts)^[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)^{#cite_ref-96}

#### Mouraria {#Mouraria}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Mouraria")\]

The Mouraria, or Moorish quarter, is one of the most traditional neighbourhoods of Lisbon,^[\[97\]](#cite_note-Carvalho2007-97)^ although most of its old buildings were demolished by the [Estado Novo](/wiki/Estado_Novo_(Portugal) "Estado Novo (Portugal)") between the 1930s and the 1970s.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-Colvin2008-98)^ It takes its name from the fact that after the reconquest of Lisbon, the Muslims who remained were confined to this part of the city.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-Soyer2007b-99)^ In turn, the Jews were confined to three neighbourhoods called "Judiarias".^[\[100\]](#cite_note-O'Flanagan2008-100)^{#cite_ref-O'Flanagan2008_100-0}  

#### Bairro Alto {#Bairro_Alto}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Bairro Alto")\]  
Main article: [Bairro Alto](/wiki/Bairro_Alto "Bairro Alto")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Bairro_Alto%2C_Lisbon_%2834487234082%29.jpg/220px-Bairro_Alto%2C_Lisbon_%2834487234082%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bairro_Alto,_Lisbon_(34487234082).jpg) *[Duke of Cadaval](/wiki/Duke_of_Cadaval "Duke of Cadaval") Square* , bordering [Bairro Alto](/wiki/Bairro_Alto "Bairro Alto") and the [Baixa Pombalina](/wiki/Baixa_Pombalina "Baixa Pombalina")

Bairro Alto (literally *the upper quarter* in [Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language")) is an area of central Lisbon that functions as a residential, shopping and entertainment district; it is the center of the Portuguese capital's nightlife, attracting hipster youth and members of various music subcultures. Lisbon's [punk](/wiki/Punk_subculture "Punk subculture"), [gay](/wiki/Gay_(term) "Gay (term)"), metal, [goth](/wiki/Goth_subculture "Goth subculture"), [hip hop](/wiki/Hip_hop_music "Hip hop music") and [reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae") scenes all find a home in the *Bairro* with its many clubs and bars that cater to them. The crowds in the Bairro Alto are a multicultural mix of people representing a broad cross-section of modern Portuguese society, many of them being entertainment seekers and devotees of various music genres outside the mainstream, [Fado](/wiki/Fado "Fado"), Portugal's national music, still survives in the midst of the new nightlife.  

#### Baixa {#Baixa}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Baixa")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/View_from_the_S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle%2C_including_the_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_on_the_waterfront.jpg/220px-View_from_the_S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle%2C_including_the_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_on_the_waterfront.jpg)](/wiki/File:View_from_the_S%C3%A3o_Jorge_Castle,_including_the_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_on_the_waterfront.jpg) View from the São Jorge Castle, including the Praça do Comércio on the waterfront  
Main article: [Baixa Pombalina](/wiki/Baixa_Pombalina "Baixa Pombalina")

The heart of the city is the *[Baixa](/wiki/Baixa "Baixa")* or city centre; the Pombaline Baixa is an elegant district, primarily constructed after the [1755 Lisbon earthquake](/wiki/1755_Lisbon_earthquake "1755 Lisbon earthquake"), taking its name from its benefactor, [Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo, 1st Marquis of Pombal](/wiki/Sebasti%C3%A3o_Jos%C3%A9_de_Carvalho_e_Melo,_1st_Marquis_of_Pombal "Sebastião José de Carvalho e Melo, 1st Marquis of Pombal"), who was the minister of [Joseph I of Portugal](/wiki/Joseph_I_of_Portugal "Joseph I of Portugal") (1750--1777) and a key figure during the Portuguese [Enlightenment](/wiki/The_Enlightenment "The Enlightenment"). Following the 1755 disaster, Pombal took the lead in rebuilding Lisbon, imposing strict conditions and guidelines on the construction of the city, and transforming the organic street plan that characterised the district before the earthquake into its current grid pattern. As a result, the Pombaline Baixa is one of the first examples of [earthquake-resistant construction](/wiki/Earthquake_construction "Earthquake construction"). Architectural models were tested by having troops march around them to simulate an earthquake. Notable features of Pombaline structures include the Pombaline cage, a symmetrical wood-lattice framework aimed at distributing earthquake forces, and inter-terrace walls that were built higher than roof timbers to inhibit the spread of fires.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Lisbon_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_pano.jpg/1000px-Lisbon_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_pano.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_pano.jpg "Praça do Comércio, with the Rua Augusta Arch, in the Lisbon Baixa")  
[](/wiki/File:Lisbon_Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio_pano.jpg "File:Lisbon Praça do Comércio pano.jpg")
[Praça do Comércio](/wiki/Pra%C3%A7a_do_Com%C3%A9rcio "Praça do Comércio"), with the [Rua Augusta Arch](/wiki/Rua_Augusta_Arch "Rua Augusta Arch"), in the [Lisbon Baixa](/wiki/Lisbon_Baixa "Lisbon Baixa")  

#### Beato {#Beato}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Beato")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Teatro_Ib%C3%A9rico_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Teatro_Ib%C3%A9rico_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Teatro_Ib%C3%A9rico_(cropped).jpg) Facade of Teatro Ibérico, in Beato

The parish of [Beato](/wiki/Beato,_Lisbon "Beato, Lisbon") stands out for the new cultural dynamics it has been experiencing in recent years. The manufacturing districts and the industrial facilities by the riverside docks are the place of choice for contemporary art galleries, iconic bars, and gourmet restaurants that simmer in the streets. This reality has not gone unnoticed by the national press, and Visão,^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^ TimeOut,^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^ or Jornal de Negócios^[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)^ have already made notice of this parish that hides treasures such as the [National Museum of the Azulejo](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_Azulejo "National Museum of the Azulejo") or the [Palacio do Grilo](/wiki/Palacio_do_Grilo "Palacio do Grilo").{#cite_ref-103}  

#### Belém {#Bel.C3.A9m}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Belém")\]  
Main article: [Belém](/wiki/Santa_Maria_de_Bel%C3%A9m "Santa Maria de Belém")

Belém is famous as the place from which many of the great [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal") explorers set off on their voyages of discovery. In particular, it is the place from which [Vasco da Gama](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama "Vasco da Gama") departed for [India](/wiki/India "India") in 1497 and Pedro Álvares Cabral departed for Brazil in 1499. It is also a former royal residence and features the 17th -- 18th-century [Belém Palace](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Palace "Belém Palace"), a former royal residence now occupied by the [President of Portugal](/wiki/President_of_Portugal "President of Portugal"), and the [Ajuda Palace](/wiki/Ajuda_Palace "Ajuda Palace"), begun in 1802 but never completed.

Perhaps Belém's most famous feature is its tower, [Torre de Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower "Belém Tower"), whose image is much used by Lisbon's tourist board. The tower was built as a fortified lighthouse late in the reign of [Dom Manuel l](/wiki/Manuel_I_of_Portugal "Manuel I of Portugal") (1515--1520) to guard the entrance to the port. It stood on a little island on the right side of the [Tagus](/wiki/Tagus "Tagus"), surrounded by water. Belém's other major historical building is the *[Mosteiro dos Jerónimos](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery,_Lisbon "Jerónimos Monastery, Lisbon")* (Jerónimos Monastery), which the [Torre de Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower "Belém Tower") was built partly to defend. Belém's most notable modern feature is the [Padrão dos Descobrimentos](/wiki/Padr%C3%A3o_dos_Descobrimentos "Padrão dos Descobrimentos") (Monument to the Discoveries) built for the Portuguese World Fair in 1940. In the heart of Belém is the *Praça do Império* : gardens centred upon a large fountain, laid out during [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"). To the west of the gardens lies the *[Centro Cultural de Belém](/wiki/Centro_Cultural_de_Bel%C3%A9m "Centro Cultural de Belém")* . Belém is one of the most visited Lisbon districts. Here is located the [Estádio do Restelo](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Restelo "Estádio do Restelo"), home to [Belenenses](/wiki/C.F._Os_Belenenses "C.F. Os Belenenses").  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/JeronimosLisbon_%28cropped%29.jpg/1000px-JeronimosLisbon_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:JeronimosLisbon_(cropped).jpg "View of Jerónimos Monastery and Praça do Império (Empire Square) from the top of the Padrão dos Descobrimentos in Belém")  
[](/wiki/File:JeronimosLisbon_(cropped).jpg "File:JeronimosLisbon (cropped).jpg")
View of [Jerónimos Monastery](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery "Jerónimos Monastery") and *Praça do Império* (Empire Square) from the top of the *[Padrão dos Descobrimentos](/wiki/Padr%C3%A3o_dos_Descobrimentos "Padrão dos Descobrimentos")* in [Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_(Lisbon) "Belém (Lisbon)")  

#### Chiado {#Chiado}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Chiado")\]  
Main article: [Chiado](/wiki/Chiado "Chiado")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/PlazaDeCamoesLisboa-P1100966-P1100968.jpg/220px-PlazaDeCamoesLisboa-P1100966-P1100968.jpg)](/wiki/File:PlazaDeCamoesLisboa-P1100966-P1100968.jpg) Monument to [Luís de Camões](/wiki/Lu%C3%ADs_de_Cam%C3%B5es "Luís de Camões"), considered the greatest poet of the [Portuguese language](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"), in [Chiado](/wiki/Chiado "Chiado")

The Chiado is a traditional shopping area that mixes old and modern commercial establishments, concentrated specially in the Rua do Carmo and the Rua Garrett. Locals as well as tourists visit the Chiado to buy books, clothing and pottery as well as to have a cup of coffee. The most famous café of Chiado is *[A Brasileira](/wiki/A_Brasileira "A Brasileira")* , famous for having had poet [Fernando Pessoa](/wiki/Fernando_Pessoa "Fernando Pessoa") among its customers. The Chiado is also an important cultural area, with several museums and theatres, including the opera. Several buildings of the Chiado were destroyed in a fire in 1988, an event that deeply shocked the country. Thanks to a renovation project that lasted more than 10 years, coordinated by celebrated architect [Siza Vieira](/wiki/Siza_Vieira "Siza Vieira"), the affected area has now virtually recovered.  

#### Estrela {#Estrela}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Estrela")\]

The ornate, late 18th-century [Estrela Basilica](/wiki/Estrela_Basilica "Estrela Basilica") is the main attraction of this district. The church with its large dome is located on a hill in what was at the time the western part of Lisbon and can be seen from great distances. The style is similar to that of the [Mafra National Palace](/wiki/Mafra_National_Palace "Mafra National Palace"), late baroque and neoclassical. The façade has twin bell towers and includes statues of saints and some allegorical figures. [São Bento Palace](/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Bento_Palace "São Bento Palace"), the seat of the Portuguese parliament and the official residences of the [Prime Minister of Portugal](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Portugal "Prime Minister of Portugal") and the President of the [Assembly of the Republic of Portugal](/wiki/Assembly_of_the_Republic_of_Portugal "Assembly of the Republic of Portugal"), are in this district. Also in this district is Estrela Park, a favorite with families. There are exotic plants and trees, a duck pond, various sculptures, a children's playground, and many cultural events going on throughout the year, including outdoor cinema, markets, and music festivals.  

#### Parque das Nações {#Parque_das_Na.C3.A7.C3.B5es}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Parque das Nações")\]  
Main article: [Parque das Nações](/wiki/Parque_das_Na%C3%A7%C3%B5es "Parque das Nações")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Lisbon_120_%2831787634704%29.jpg/220px-Lisbon_120_%2831787634704%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_120_(31787634704).jpg) The [Parque das Nações](/wiki/Parque_das_Na%C3%A7%C3%B5es "Parque das Nações") district was initially built for the [Lisbon World Expo](/wiki/Expo_%2798 "Expo '98").

Parque das Nações (Park of Nations) is the newest district in Lisbon; it emerged from an urban renewal program to host the 1998 World Exhibition of Lisbon, also known as Expo'98. The area suffered massive changes giving Parque das Nações a futuristic look. A long-lasting legacy of the same, the area has become another commercial and higher-end residential area for the city.

Central in the area is the [Gare do Oriente](/wiki/Gare_do_Oriente "Gare do Oriente") (Orient railway station), one of the main transport hubs of Lisbon for trains, buses, taxis, and the metro. Its glass and steel columns are inspired by Gothic architecture, lending the whole structure a visual fascination (especially in sunlight or when illuminated at night). It was designed by the architect [Santiago Calatrava](/wiki/Santiago_Calatrava "Santiago Calatrava") from [Valencia](/wiki/Valencia "Valencia"), Spain. The Parque das Nações is across the street.

The area is pedestrian-friendly with new buildings, restaurants, gardens, the [Casino Lisbon](/wiki/Casino_Lisboa,_Portugal "Casino Lisboa, Portugal"), the FIL building (International Exhibition and Fair), the Camões Theatre and the *Oceanário de Lisboa* ([Lisbon Oceanarium](/wiki/Lisbon_Oceanarium "Lisbon Oceanarium")), which is the second-largest in the world. The district's [Altice Arena](/wiki/Altice_Arena "Altice Arena") has become Lisbon's "jack-of-all-trades" performance arena. With seating for 20,000, it has staged events ranging from concerts to basketball tournaments.
