Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Culture")\]  
See also: [Tourism in Lisbon](/wiki/Tourism_in_Lisbon "Tourism in Lisbon")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Lisbon_2015_10_14_0648_%2823515641921%29.jpg/220px-Lisbon_2015_10_14_0648_%2823515641921%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_2015_10_14_0648_(23515641921).jpg) The [National Coach Museum](/wiki/National_Coach_Museum "National Coach Museum") has the largest collection of royal carriages in the world and is one of Lisbon's most visited institutions. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Museu_Nacional_de_Arte_Antiga2075_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Museu_Nacional_de_Arte_Antiga2075_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museu_Nacional_de_Arte_Antiga2075_(cropped).jpg) The [National Museum of Ancient Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ancient_Art "National Museum of Ancient Art") has one of the [largest art collections in the world](/wiki/List_of_largest_art_museums "List of largest art museums").

The city of Lisbon is rich in architecture; [Romanesque](/wiki/Romanesque_architecture "Romanesque architecture"), [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture"), [Manueline](/wiki/Manueline "Manueline"), [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque"), [Modern](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism") and [Postmodern](/wiki/Postmodern "Postmodern") constructions can be found all over Lisbon. The city is also crossed by historical boulevards and monuments along the main thoroughfares, particularly in the upper districts; notable among these are the *[Avenida da Liberdade](/wiki/Avenida_da_Liberdade "Avenida da Liberdade")* (Avenue of Liberty), *Avenida Fontes Pereira de Melo* , *Avenida Almirante Reis* and *Avenida da República* (Avenue of the Republic).

Lisbon is home to numerous prominent museums and art collections, from all around the world. The [National Museum of Ancient Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Ancient_Art "National Museum of Ancient Art"), which has one of the [largest art collections in the world](/wiki/List_of_largest_art_museums "List of largest art museums"), and the [National Coach Museum](/wiki/National_Coach_Museum "National Coach Museum"), which has the world's largest collection of royal coaches and carriages, are the two most visited museums in the city. Other notable national museums include the [National Museum of Archaeology](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Archaeology,_Lisbon "National Museum of Archaeology, Lisbon"), the [Museum of Lisbon](/wiki/Museum_of_Lisbon "Museum of Lisbon"), the [National Azulejo Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_Azulejo "National Museum of the Azulejo"), the [National Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_of_Chiado "National Museum of Contemporary Art of Chiado"), and the [National Museum of Natural History \& Science](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Natural_History_and_Science,_Lisbon "National Museum of Natural History and Science, Lisbon").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg/220px-Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Torre_Bel%C3%A9m_April_2009-4a.jpg) The [Belém Tower](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower "Belém Tower"), one of the most famous and visited landmarks in Lisbon and throughout Portugal

Prominent private museums and galleries include the [Gulbenkian Museum](/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Museum "Calouste Gulbenkian Museum") (run by the [Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation](/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Foundation "Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation"), one of the [wealthiest foundations in the world](/wiki/List_of_wealthiest_charitable_foundations "List of wealthiest charitable foundations")), which houses one of the largest private collections of antiquities and art in the world, the [Contemporary Art Museum - Centro Cultural de Belém](/wiki/Berardo_Collection_Museum "Berardo Collection Museum"), the [Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology](/wiki/Museum_of_Art,_Architecture_and_Technology "Museum of Art, Architecture and Technology"), and the [Museum of the Orient](/wiki/Museum_of_the_Orient "Museum of the Orient"). Other popular museums include the [Electricity Museum](/wiki/Electricity_Museum "Electricity Museum"), the [Ephemeral Museum](/wiki/Ephemeral_Museum "Ephemeral Museum"), the [Museu da Água](/wiki/Museu_da_%C3%81gua "Museu da Água"), and the [Museu Benfica](/wiki/Museu_Benfica "Museu Benfica"), among many others.

Lisbon's Opera House, the *[Teatro Nacional de São Carlos](/wiki/Teatro_Nacional_de_S%C3%A3o_Carlos "Teatro Nacional de São Carlos")* , hosts a relatively active cultural agenda, mainly in autumn and winter. Other important theatres and musical houses are the *[Centro Cultural de Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Cultural_Center "Belém Cultural Center")* , the *[Teatro Nacional D. Maria II](/wiki/D._Maria_II_National_Theatre "D. Maria II National Theatre")* , the [Gulbenkian Foundation](/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Foundation "Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation"), and the *Teatro Camões*.

The monument to *Christ the King* ([Cristo-Rei](/wiki/Christ_the_King_(Almada) "Christ the King (Almada)")) stands on the southern bank of the Tagus River, in [Almada](/wiki/Almada "Almada"). With open arms, overlooking the whole city, it resembles the Corcovado monument in [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), and was built after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), as a memorial of thanksgiving for Portugal's being spared the horrors and destruction of the war.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Museo_gulbekian%2C_sala_del_mobilio_francese.jpg/220px-Museo_gulbekian%2C_sala_del_mobilio_francese.jpg)](/wiki/File:Museo_gulbekian,_sala_del_mobilio_francese.jpg) The [Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation](/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Foundation "Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation") is one of the [wealthiest foundations in the world](/wiki/List_of_wealthiest_charitable_foundations "List of wealthiest charitable foundations") and houses one of the largest private collections of antiquaries and art in the world, within the [Gulbenkian Museum](/wiki/Calouste_Gulbenkian_Museum "Calouste Gulbenkian Museum").

13 June is Lisbon's holiday in honour of the city's saint, [Anthony of Lisbon](/wiki/Anthony_of_Lisbon "Anthony of Lisbon") ([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Santo António* ). Saint Anthony, also known as *Saint Anthony of Padua* , was a wealthy Portuguese bohemian who was [canonised](/wiki/Canonization "Canonization") and made [Doctor of the Church](/wiki/Doctor_of_the_Church "Doctor of the Church") after a life preaching to the poor. Although Lisbon's patron saint is Saint [Vincent of Saragossa](/wiki/Vincent_of_Saragossa "Vincent of Saragossa"), whose remains are housed in the [Sé Cathedral](/wiki/Lisbon_Cathedral "Lisbon Cathedral"), there are no festivities associated with this saint.

[Eduardo VII Park](/wiki/Eduardo_VII_Park "Eduardo VII Park"), the second-largest park in the city following the *Parque Florestal de Monsanto* ([Monsanto Forest Park](/wiki/Monsanto_Forest_Park "Monsanto Forest Park")), extends down the main avenue ([Avenida da Liberdade](/wiki/Avenida_da_Liberdade "Avenida da Liberdade")), with many flowering plants and green spaces, that includes the permanent collection of subtropical and tropical plants in the winter garden ([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): *Estufa Fria* ). Originally named *Parque da Liberdade* , it was renamed in honour of [Edward VII](/wiki/Edward_VII "Edward VII") who visited Lisbon in 1903.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/P%C3%A7a._do_Rossio_-_Lisboa_%28Portugal%29.jpg/220px-P%C3%A7a._do_Rossio_-_Lisboa_%28Portugal%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:P%C3%A7a._do_Rossio_-_Lisboa_(Portugal).jpg) [Rossio Square](/wiki/Rossio_Square "Rossio Square"), with [Queen Maria II National Theatre](/wiki/D._Maria_II_National_Theatre "D. Maria II National Theatre") in the background

Lisbon is home every year to the [Lisbon Gay \& Lesbian Film Festival](/wiki/Queer_Lisboa_International_Queer_Film_Festival "Queer Lisboa International Queer Film Festival"),^[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)^ the Lisboarte, the DocLisboa -- Lisbon International Documentary Film Festival,^[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)^ the Festival Internacional de Máscaras e Comediantes, the Lisboa Mágica -- Street Magic World Festival, the Monstra -- Animated Film Festival, the [Lisbon Book Fair](/wiki/Lisbon_Book_Fair "Lisbon Book Fair"),^[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)^ the Peixe em Lisboa -- Lisbon Fish and Flavours,^[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)^ and many others.{#cite_ref-108}

Lisbon has two sites listed by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") as a [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site"): [Belém Tower](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m_Tower "Belém Tower") and [Jerónimos Monastery](/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimos_Monastery "Jerónimos Monastery"). Furthermore, in 1994, Lisbon was the [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") and, in 1998, organised the [Expo '98](/wiki/Expo_%2798 "Expo '98") (*1998 Lisbon World Exposition*).

Lisbon is also home to the Lisbon Architecture Triennial,^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^ the Moda Lisboa (Fashion Lisbon),^[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)^ ExperimentaDesign -- Biennial of Design,^[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)^ and LuzBoa -- Biennial of Light.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}

Lisbon hosts many fine examples of Portuguese [azulejo](/wiki/Azulejo "Azulejo") tile art, a use of ceramic tile as an architectural finish for both building interiors and exteriors dating from the 15th Century. This art form is celebrated in Lisbon's [National Museum of the Azulejo](/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_Azulejo "National Museum of the Azulejo") and as a station feature in the [Lisbon metro](/wiki/Lisbon_metro "Lisbon metro"). In addition, the mosaic [Portuguese pavement](/wiki/Portuguese_pavement "Portuguese pavement") (*Calçada Portuguesa*) was born in Lisbon, in the mid-1800s. The art has since spread to the rest of the Portuguese Speaking world. The city remains one of the most expansive examples of the technique, nearly all walkways and even many streets being created and maintained in this style.

In May 2018, the city hosted the [63rd edition of the Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2018 "Eurovision Song Contest 2018"), after the victory of [Salvador Sobral](/wiki/Salvador_Sobral "Salvador Sobral") with the song "*[Amar pelos dois](/wiki/Amar_pelos_dois "Amar pelos dois")* " in [Kyiv](/wiki/Kyiv "Kyiv") on 13 May 2017.

[World Youth Day 2023](/wiki/World_Youth_Day_2023 "World Youth Day 2023") was hosted in August of that year in Lisbon, attracting hundreds of thousands of young Catholics from over 140 countries.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)^{#cite_ref-113}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Demographics")\]

[Historical population]

The historical population of the city was around 35,000 in 1300 . This number went up to 60,000 in 1400, and raised to 70,000 by 1500. Between 1528 and 1590 the population went from 70,000 to 120,000. The population was about 150,000 in 1600, and almost 200,000 in 1700.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}

Lisbon has 567,131 inhabitants within the administrative center on the area of only 100.05 km^2^^[\[3\]](#cite_note-dgt-3)^ The population density of the city itself is 5,668.5/km^2^ (14,681/sq mi).{#cite_ref-dgt_3-1}

The Lisbon metropolitan area incorporates two [NUTS III](/wiki/NUTS_III "NUTS III") (European statistical subdivisions): *[Grande Lisboa](/wiki/Grande_Lisboa "Grande Lisboa")* (Greater Lisbon), along the northern bank of the [Tagus River](/wiki/Tagus_River "Tagus River"), and *[Península de Setúbal](/wiki/Pen%C3%ADnsula_de_Set%C3%BAbal "Península de Setúbal")* (Setúbal Peninsula), along the southern bank. These two subdivisions make for the *[Região de Lisboa](/wiki/Regi%C3%A3o_de_Lisboa "Região de Lisboa")* (Lisbon Region).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lisbon_population_pyramid.svg/220px-Lisbon_population_pyramid.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_population_pyramid.svg) Lisbon population pyramid in 2021

Administratively defined cities that exist in the vicinity of the capital are in fact part of the metropolitan perimeter of Lisbon. The urban area has, according to Government data, a population of approximately 2.96 million inhabitants and is the eleventh largest urban area in the European Union.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-World_Urban_Areas-11)^^[\[10\]](#cite_note-Statistics_Portugal_-_Web_Portal-10)^ Other sources also show similar figures: according to the [Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development](/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development "Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development") the area had 2,797,612 inhabitants;^[\[118\]](#cite_note-118)^ according to the Department of Economic and Social Affairs of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") 2,890,000;^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^ according to the European Statistical Office [Eurostat](/wiki/Eurostat "Eurostat") 2,839,908^[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)^ and according to the [Brookings Institution](/wiki/Brookings_Institution "Brookings Institution") 2,968,600.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^{#cite_ref-121}

Lisbon's population has steadily dropped over the years due to people searching better accommodations for lower prices elsewhere in Greater Lisbon. A reverse trend has been observed in recent years, with the population increasing to 567,131 people in 2023, an all-time high since 2001 census and a 4.52% increase since the 2011 census.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-:3-122)^{#cite_ref-:3_122-0}

In addition, a plurality of the houses in the city centre have become tourist facilities, exacerbating the lack of offer in Lisbon's housing market.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-123)^^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^^[\[125\]](#cite_note-125)^^[\[126\]](#cite_note-126)^{#cite_ref-126}

The proportion of Catholics in Lisbon city proper (around 66%) is significantly higher than in the city's metropolitan area (55%).^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^ This may due to the fact that Lisbon city's age structure is older than the one found in the surrounding areas and, in general, younger generations tend to be less religious.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^{#cite_ref-130}  

### Immigration {#Immigration}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Immigration")\]

In 2019 around 17.48% of the population residing within the city's boundaries held a foreign nationality, a share that stood at 8.87% in 2014. In general, the increase in Lisbon's population is essentially attributable to the influx of people coming from abroad, who have more than tripled since 2017. Around 5.89% of Lisbon's population was constituted by Brazilians as of 2023, not including those also holding Portuguese nationality.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-131)^^[\[122\]](#cite_note-:3-122)^{#cite_ref-:3_122-1}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Avenida_da_Liberdade_%2822344060581%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avenida_da_Liberdade_(22344060581)_(cropped).jpg) [Avenida da Liberdade](/wiki/Avenida_da_Liberdade "Avenida da Liberdade") is one of the [most expensive shopping streets in Europe](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_streets_by_city "List of most expensive streets by city") and famous as a popular destination for [luxury goods](/wiki/Luxury_goods "Luxury goods") shopping.

The [Lisbon region](/wiki/Grande_Lisboa "Grande Lisboa") is the wealthiest region in Portugal, with a GDP per capita of nearly €40,000, and it is well above the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union")'s [GDP per capita](/wiki/GDP_per_capita "GDP per capita") average -- it produces more than 31% of Portuguese GDP by 2023.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^{#cite_ref-134}

The Lisbon region is rapidly growing, with GDP (PPP) per capita calculated for each year as follows: €22,745 (2004)^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^ -- €23,816 (2005)^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^ -- €25,200 (2006)^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^ -- €26,100 (2007).^[\[138\]](#cite_note-138)^ The Lisbon metropolitan area had a [GDP amounting to $110.4 billion](/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP "List of cities by GDP"), and $32,434 per capita.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-Brookings-139)^{#cite_ref-Brookings_139-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Rio_Arauca_at_the_oil_terminal_in_Lisboa_%282017%29.jpg/220px-Rio_Arauca_at_the_oil_terminal_in_Lisboa_%282017%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rio_Arauca_at_the_oil_terminal_in_Lisboa_(2017).jpg) The oil tanker *Rio Arauca* at the oil terminal in Lisboa to unload crude oil

Lisbon's economy is based primarily on the [tertiary sector](/wiki/Tertiary_sector "Tertiary sector"). Most of the headquarters of multinationals operating in Portugal are concentrated in the [Grande Lisboa Subregion](/wiki/Grande_Lisboa_Subregion "Grande Lisboa Subregion"), especially in the [Oeiras](/wiki/Oeiras_Municipality,_Portugal "Oeiras Municipality, Portugal") municipality. The [Lisbon metropolitan area](/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area "Lisbon metropolitan area") is heavily industrialized, especially the south bank of the [Tagus](/wiki/Tagus "Tagus") river (Rio Tejo). The lisbonite industry has very large sectors in oil, as refineries are found just across the Tagus, textile mills, shipyards and fishing.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/By_the_river_%2834263121734%29.jpg/220px-By_the_river_%2834263121734%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:By_the_river_(34263121734).jpg) The [Port of Lisbon](/wiki/Port_of_Lisbon "Port of Lisbon") is one of the busiest ports in Europe.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^

The country's chief [seaport](/wiki/Port_of_Lisbon "Port of Lisbon"), featuring one of the largest and most sophisticated regional markets on the Iberian Peninsula, Lisbon and its heavily populated surroundings are also developing as an important financial centre and a dynamic technological hub. Automobile manufacturers have erected factories in the suburbs, for example, [AutoEuropa](/wiki/AutoEuropa "AutoEuropa").

Lisbon has the largest and most developed mass media sector of Portugal and is home to several related companies ranging from leading television networks and radio stations to [major newspapers](/wiki/Newspaper_of_record "Newspaper of record"). Based in Lisbon, [Euronext Lisbon](/wiki/Euronext_Lisbon "Euronext Lisbon") is a [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange") which is part of the pan-European [Euronext](/wiki/Euronext "Euronext") system of stock exchanges and market infrastructure.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^{#cite_ref-141}

Before Portugal's sovereign debt crisis and an [EU-IMF rescue plan](/wiki/Portuguese_economic_crisis_of_the_2010s "Portuguese economic crisis of the 2010s"), for the decade of 2010 Lisbon was expecting to receive many state-funded investments, including building a new airport, a new bridge, an expansion of the Lisbon Metro 30 km (18.64 mi) underground, the construction of a mega-hospital (or central hospital), the creation of two lines of a [TGV](/wiki/TGV "TGV") to join [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), [Porto](/wiki/Porto "Porto"), [Vigo](/wiki/Vigo "Vigo") and the rest of Europe, the restoration of the main part of the town (between the Marquês de Pombal roundabout and Terreiro do Paço), the creation of a large number of bike lanes, as well as modernization and renovation of various facilities.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}

The sovereign debt crisis exacerbated poor labor conditions and low purchasing power. Although the city modernized its infrastructure and experienced significant tourism growth and income, this reality was not proportionally reflected in the average living conditions. Prices generally increased, but wages did not follow this trend. Labor conditions remain far below the standards of the rest of the European Union (EU).^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^^[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}

Therefore, Lisbon is still the European capital with some of the lowest wages and purchasing power within the EU. Energy, electricity, gas, and fuel, as well as supermarkets and housing, are among the most expensive, even compared to the richest countries in Europe.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)^^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^ The gap between the highest and lowest wages is the largest within the eurozone. The minimum wage can be as low as 6-7 euros per hour.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)^^[\[151\]](#cite_note-151)^ Due to these reasons, Lisbon has a high level of youth emigration, mostly to other European countries such as France, the UK, Luxembourg, Switzerland, and Belgium.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)^^[\[153\]](#cite_note-153)^^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

Lisbon was the [7th most "livable city" in the world](/wiki/World%27s_most_livable_cities#Most_Liveable_Cities_Index "World's most livable cities") in 2021 according to lifestyle magazine *[Monocle](/wiki/Monocle_(2007_magazine) "Monocle (2007 magazine)").* ^[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}

Tourism is also a significant industry. The city is the ninth-most-visited city in [Southern Europe](/wiki/Southern_Europe "Southern Europe"), after [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), [Milan](/wiki/Milan "Milan"), [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), [Venice](/wiki/Venice "Venice"), [Madrid](/wiki/Madrid "Madrid") and [Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence") with 3,639,900 tourists in 2019.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)^^[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)^ In 2022 there were around 6 tourists for every resident.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-159)^ The city is popular for both leisure and business tourism.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)^^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^ Around 7.7 million tourists visited Lisbon region in 2022 alone, with 71.1% of them being international tourists.^[\[162\]](#cite_note-162)^ It is estimated that tourist receipts will stand at 17.4 billion euros ([€](/wiki/%E2%82%AC "€")) in 2023.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Transport")\]  

### Metro {#Metro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Metro")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/HPIM0530_%28cropped%29.JPG/220px-HPIM0530_%28cropped%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:HPIM0530_(cropped).JPG) The [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro") is Portugal's oldest and largest subway system.  
Main article: [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro")

The [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro") connects the city centre with the upper and eastern districts, and also reaches some suburbs that are part of the [Lisbon metropolitan area](/wiki/Lisbon_metropolitan_area "Lisbon metropolitan area"), such as [Amadora](/wiki/Amadora "Amadora") and [Loures](/wiki/Loures "Loures"). It is the fastest way to get around the city and it provides a good number of interchanging stations with other types of transportation. From the [Lisbon Airport](/wiki/Lisbon_Airport "Lisbon Airport") station to the city centre it may take roughly 25 mins. In 2019, the [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro") served around 173 million passengers (and 475.000 daily). As of 2018, the [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro") comprises four lines, identified by individual colours (blue, yellow, green and red) and 56 stations, with a total length of 44.2 km. Several expansion projects have been proposed, the most recent being the transformation of the Green Line into a circular line and the creation of two more stations (Santos and [Estrela](/wiki/Estrela_(Lisbon) "Estrela (Lisbon)")).  

### Trams {#Trams}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Trams")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Lisbon_tram_next_to_Lisbon_Cathedral.jpg/220px-Lisbon_tram_next_to_Lisbon_Cathedral.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_tram_next_to_Lisbon_Cathedral.jpg) A [Lisbon tram](/wiki/Trams_in_Lisbon "Trams in Lisbon") by [Lisbon Cathedral](/wiki/Lisbon_Cathedral "Lisbon Cathedral") and [Santo António Church](/wiki/Santo_Ant%C3%B3nio_Church "Santo António Church")  
Main article: [Trams in Lisbon](/wiki/Trams_in_Lisbon "Trams in Lisbon")

The [tram](/wiki/Tram "Tram") is a traditional form of public transport in Lisbon. Introduced in 1901, electric trams were originally imported from the US,^[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)^ and thus called the *americanos* ([Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language") for "American"). Today these trams are called *elétricos* (literally meaning electric ones).{#cite_ref-164}

Other than on the modern Line 15, the [Lisbon tramway system](/wiki/Trams_in_Lisbon "Trams in Lisbon") still employs small (four-wheel) vehicles of a design dating from the early twentieth century. These distinctive yellow trams are one of the tourist icons of modern Lisbon, and their size is well suited to the steep hills and narrow streets of the central city.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-165)^^[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}

The earliest trams can still be seen in the [Museu da Carris](/wiki/Carris_Museum "Carris Museum") (the Lisbon Public Transport Museum).

The line has now a total length of 31 kilometers operating on 6 lines, down from a maximum of 76 kilometers for 27 lines. The slow decline of the network began with the construction of the [Lisbon Metro](/wiki/Lisbon_Metro "Lisbon Metro") and the expansion of the [bus system](/wiki/Carris "Carris").^[\[167\]](#cite_note-167)^ Starting in 2017 the system has been expanded and new vehicles are being progressively added, aiming at expanding significantly the current tramway system.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-168)^^[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)^^[\[170\]](#cite_note-170)^ There are currently 64 trams in operation in Lisbon and, during 2023-2026, 35 more will be added (Of which 10 will be "Historical models").^[\[171\]](#cite_note-171)^^[\[172\]](#cite_note-172)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-173)^^[\[174\]](#cite_note-:2-174)^{#cite_ref-:2_174-0}  

### Trains {#Trains}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Trains")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Oriente%2C_Lisboa%2C_Portugal_%2819198862262%29.jpg/220px-Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Oriente%2C_Lisboa%2C_Portugal_%2819198862262%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Oriente,_Lisboa,_Portugal_(19198862262).jpg) [Gare do Oriente](/wiki/Gare_do_Oriente "Gare do Oriente") train station, designed by [Santiago Calatrava](/wiki/Santiago_Calatrava "Santiago Calatrava")

There are four [commuter train](/wiki/CP_Urban_Services "CP Urban Services") lines departing from Lisbon: the Sintra, Azambuja, Cascais and Sado lines (operated by CP -- [Comboios de Portugal](/wiki/Comboios_de_Portugal "Comboios de Portugal")), as well as a fifth line to [Setúbal](/wiki/Set%C3%BAbal "Setúbal") (operated by [Fertagus](/wiki/Fertagus "Fertagus")), which crosses the [Tagus](/wiki/Tagus "Tagus") river via the [25 de Abril Bridge](/wiki/25_de_Abril_Bridge "25 de Abril Bridge"). The major railway stations are [Santa Apolónia](/wiki/Santa_Apol%C3%B3nia_railway_station "Santa Apolónia railway station"), [Rossio](/wiki/Rossio_railway_station "Rossio railway station"), [Gare do Oriente](/wiki/Gare_do_Oriente "Gare do Oriente"), [Entrecampos](/wiki/Entrecampos_railway_station "Entrecampos railway station"), and [Cais do Sodré](/wiki/Cais_do_Sodr%C3%A9_railway_station "Cais do Sodré railway station").  

### Buses {#Buses}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Buses")\]

The local bus service within Lisbon is operated by [Carris](/wiki/Carris "Carris"). Carris' fleet includes 741 buses and, in the period 2023-2026, other 342 buses will be added so as to increase the public transportation system reach.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-175)^^[\[174\]](#cite_note-:2-174)^ The [bus network](/wiki/Bus "Bus") has a length of 748 km comprising 99 bus routes.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-176)^ Major investments have been made in recent years: for instance, in 2017 there were 600 buses operating on 674 km and 75 routes: 141 buses, 74 kilometers and 24 bus routes were added in 2018-2022.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

Outside Lisbon, there are two main commuter bus services connecting the cities outside Lisbon amongst them and to Lisbon: Carris Metropolitana,^[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)^ a brand operated by 4 companies, all operating inside the Lisbon Metropolitan Area, and Barraqueiro Transportes^[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)^ (with 4 brands operating outside the Metropolitan Area with services to Lisbon), which operate from different terminals in the city.{#cite_ref-179}  

### Bridges {#Bridges}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Bridges")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/25_de_Abril_Bridge_%2836831608556%29.jpg/220px-25_de_Abril_Bridge_%2836831608556%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:25_de_Abril_Bridge_(36831608556).jpg) The [25 de Abril Bridge](/wiki/25_de_Abril_Bridge "25 de Abril Bridge") crosses the [Tagus River](/wiki/Tagus_River "Tagus River") from [Alcântara](/wiki/Alc%C3%A2ntara_(Lisbon) "Alcântara (Lisbon)") to [Almada](/wiki/Almada "Almada") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge.jpg/220px-Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge.jpg) Vasco da Gama bridge crosses the Tagus from [Parque das Nações](/wiki/Parque_das_Na%C3%A7%C3%B5es "Parque das Nações") to [Montijo](/wiki/Montijo,_Portugal "Montijo, Portugal")

The city is connected to the far side of the Tagus by two important bridges:

* The [25 de Abril Bridge](/wiki/25_de_Abril_Bridge "25 de Abril Bridge"), inaugurated (as Ponte [Salazar](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_de_Oliveira_Salazar "António de Oliveira Salazar")) on 6 August 1966, and later renamed after the date of the [Carnation Revolution](/wiki/Carnation_Revolution "Carnation Revolution"), was the longest [suspension bridge](/wiki/Suspension_bridge "Suspension bridge") in Europe.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-180)^{#cite_ref-180}
* The [Vasco da Gama Bridge](/wiki/Vasco_da_Gama_Bridge "Vasco da Gama Bridge"), opened on 29 March 1998 is, at 17.2 km (10.7 mi), the longest bridge in Europe.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}

The foundations for a [third bridge across the Tagus](/wiki/Third_Tagus_Crossing "Third Tagus Crossing") have already been laid, but the overall project has been postponed due to economic crisis that affected Portugal, and other bureaucratic and political reasons.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-182)^^[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)^{#cite_ref-183}  

### Ferries {#Ferries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Ferries")\]

Another way of crossing the river is by taking the ferry.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)^ The operator [Transtejo \& Soflusa](/wiki/Transtejo_%26_Soflusa "Transtejo & Soflusa"),^[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)^ runs to different locations from within the city: [Cacilhas](/wiki/Cacilhas "Cacilhas"), [Seixal](/wiki/Seixal_Municipality "Seixal Municipality"), [Montijo](/wiki/Montijo,_Portugal "Montijo, Portugal"), [Porto Brandão](/wiki/Porto_Brand%C3%A3o "Porto Brandão") and [Trafaria](/wiki/Trafaria "Trafaria") under the brand Transtejo and to [Barreiro](/wiki/Barreiro_(city) "Barreiro (city)") under the brand Soflusa. Ferry stations in Lisbon include [Belém Station](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esta%C3%A7%C3%A3o_Fluvial_de_Bel%C3%A9m "pt:Estação Fluvial de Belém"), [Terreiro do Paço River Station](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_Fluvial_do_Terreiro_do_Pa%C3%A7o "pt:Terminal Fluvial do Terreiro do Paço") and [Cais do Sodré River Station](https://pt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_Fluvial_do_Cais_do_Sodr%C3%A9 "pt:Terminal Fluvial do Cais do Sodré").{#cite_ref-185}  

### Air travel {#Air_travel}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Air travel")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Lissabon_Airport.jpeg/220px-Lissabon_Airport.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Lissabon_Airport.jpeg) Lisbon airport

[Humberto Delgado Airport](/wiki/Lisbon_Airport "Lisbon Airport") is located within the city limits.

It is the headquarters and hub for [TAP Portugal](/wiki/TAP_Portugal "TAP Portugal") as well as a hub for [EasyJet](/wiki/EasyJet "EasyJet"), [Azores Airlines](/wiki/Azores_Airlines "Azores Airlines"), [Ryanair](/wiki/Ryanair "Ryanair"), [EuroAtlantic Airways](/wiki/EuroAtlantic_Airways "EuroAtlantic Airways"), [White Airways](/wiki/White_Airways "White Airways"), and [Hi Fly](/wiki/Hi_Fly_(airline) "Hi Fly (airline)"). Having served 35.1 million passengers in 2024, it is by far the busiest airport in Portugal, the third busiest in the Iberian Peninsula and the 12th [busiest in Europe](/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe "List of the busiest airports in Europe").^[\[186\]](#cite_note-Vinci1-186)^{#cite_ref-Vinci1_186-0}

A second airport has been proposed and the project was initially put on hold because of the Portuguese and European economic crisis, and also because of the long discussion on whether a new airport is needed. In 2023 there were still 9 possible sites who are thought to be able to host the future New Lisbon airport.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-187)^^[\[188\]](#cite_note-188)^ Finally, in 2024, the new government announced that the new international airport would be located in Alcochete, just across the Tagus from Lisbon.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}

[Cascais Municipal Aerodrome](/wiki/Cascais_Municipal_Aerodrome "Cascais Municipal Aerodrome"), 20 km West of the city centre and hub for [Sevenair](/wiki/Sevenair_Air_Services "Sevenair Air Services"), in [Cascais](/wiki/Cascais "Cascais"), offers commercial domestic flights to [Bragança](/wiki/Bragan%C3%A7a_Airport "Bragança Airport"), [Portimão](/wiki/Portim%C3%A3o_Airport "Portimão Airport"), [Viseu](/wiki/Viseu_Airport "Viseu Airport") and [Vila Real](/wiki/Vila_Real_Airport "Vila Real Airport"). This location is where many of the country's aviation schools are concentrated.  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Cycling")\]  
See also: [Gira (bicycle rental)](/wiki/Gira_(bicycle_rental) "Gira (bicycle rental)")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Lisbon_%2845923876392%29.jpg/220px-Lisbon_%2845923876392%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lisbon_(45923876392).jpg) Gira recharging station

Following the Covid-19 pandemic, Lisbon has seen a significant increase in cycling and plans to expand the current Gira [bike hire system](/wiki/Bike_rental "Bike rental") from 1,600 bikes to 2,600 by the end of 2023.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)^ Many of these bicycles are [electric](/wiki/Electric_bicycle "Electric bicycle") to deal with Lisbon's hills.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-191)^ The city also plans to expand the number of bike recharging stations, now standing at 146. Gira service is integrated in the public transportation system, as youth up to 23 years old and seniors over 65 years old can use the service for free, while for other residents bikes are included in the Navegante card.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-192)^^[\[193\]](#cite_note-193)^{#cite_ref-193}

In 2023 there were over 200 kilometers of bike lanes within the city's administrative area and the city plans to expand its network of cycle paths in the next years.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-194)^^[\[195\]](#cite_note-195)^^[\[196\]](#cite_note-196)^^[\[197\]](#cite_note-197)^{#cite_ref-197}  

### Public transportation statistics {#Public_transportation_statistics}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Public transportation statistics")\]

The average amount of time people spend commuting with public transit in Lisbon, for example to and from work, on a weekday is 59 min. 11.5% of public transit riders, ride for more than 2 hours every day. The average amount of time people wait at a stop or station for public transit is 14 min, while 23.1% of riders wait for over 20 minutes on average every day. The average distance people usually ride in a single trip with public transit is 6 km, while 10% travel for over 12 km in a single direction.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}  

### Car {#Car}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Car")\]

Lisbon is connected to its suburbs and throughout Portugal by an extensive motorway network. There are three circular motorways around the city; the 2ª Circular, the IC17 (CRIL), and the A9 (CREL).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Univ_Nova_Lisboa.jpg/220px-Univ_Nova_Lisboa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Univ_Nova_Lisboa.jpg) The rectory and main campus of the [New University of Lisbon](/wiki/New_University_of_Lisbon "New University of Lisbon")  

### International schools {#International_schools}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: International schools")\]

In [Greater Lisbon](/wiki/Greater_Lisbon "Greater Lisbon") area, particularly in the [Portuguese Riviera](/wiki/Portuguese_Riviera "Portuguese Riviera"), an area popular with [expats](/wiki/Expats "Expats") and foreign nationals, there are numerous [international schools](/wiki/International_school "International school"), including the [Carlucci American International School of Lisbon](/wiki/Carlucci_American_International_School_of_Lisbon "Carlucci American International School of Lisbon") (only American school in Portugal), [Saint Julian's School](/wiki/Saint_Julian%27s_School "Saint Julian's School") (British), [Saint Dominic's International School](/wiki/Saint_Dominic%27s_International_School "Saint Dominic's International School") (British), [Deutsche Schule Lissabon](/wiki/Deutsche_Schule_Lissabon "Deutsche Schule Lissabon") (German), [Instituto Español Giner de los Ríos](/wiki/Instituto_Espa%C3%B1ol_Giner_de_los_R%C3%ADos "Instituto Español Giner de los Ríos") (Spanish), [Oerias Internacional Schoo](/wiki/Oeiras_International_School "Oeiras International School")l (IB), and [Lycée Français Charles Lepierre](/wiki/Lyc%C3%A9e_Fran%C3%A7ais_Charles_Lepierre "Lycée Français Charles Lepierre") (French).  

### Higher education {#Higher_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Higher education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Fontana_Liminosa_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/220px-Fontana_Liminosa_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fontana_Liminosa_-_panoramio_(1).jpg) [Instituto Superior Técnico](/wiki/Instituto_Superior_T%C3%A9cnico "Instituto Superior Técnico"), which belongs to the University of Lisbon is based on the Alameda D. Afonso Henriques.

In the city, there are three [public universities](/wiki/Public_universities "Public universities") and a [university institute](/wiki/University_institute "University institute"). The [University of Lisbon](/wiki/University_of_Lisbon "University of Lisbon"), which is the largest university in Portugal, was created in 2013 with the union of the [Technical University of Lisbon](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Lisbon "Technical University of Lisbon") and the Classical University of Lisbon (which was known as the University of Lisbon). The [New University of Lisbon](/wiki/New_University_of_Lisbon "New University of Lisbon"), founded in 1973, is another public university in Lisbon and is known internationally by its [Nova School of Business and Economics](/wiki/Nova_School_of_Business_and_Economics "Nova School of Business and Economics") (Nova SBE), its economics and management faculty. The third public university is [Universidade Aberta](/wiki/Universidade_Aberta "Universidade Aberta"). Additionally, there's [ISCTE - Lisbon University Institute](/wiki/ISCTE_-_Lisbon_University_Institute "ISCTE - Lisbon University Institute") (founded in 1972), a university institute that provides degrees in all academic disciplines.

Major private institutions of higher education include the [Portuguese Catholic University](/wiki/Portuguese_Catholic_University "Portuguese Catholic University"), focused on law and management, as well as the Lusíada University, the [Universidade Lusófona](/wiki/Universidade_Lus%C3%B3fona "Universidade Lusófona"), and the [Universidade Autónoma de Lisboa](/wiki/Universidade_Aut%C3%B3noma_de_Lisboa "Universidade Autónoma de Lisboa"), among others.

The total number of enrolled students in higher education in Lisbon was, for the 2007--2008 school year, of 125,867 students, of whom 81,507 in the Lisbon's public institutions.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-199)^{#cite_ref-199}  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Libraries")\]

Lisbon is home to [Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal](/wiki/Biblioteca_Nacional_de_Portugal "Biblioteca Nacional de Portugal"), the Portuguese national library, which has over 3 million books and manuscripts. The library has some rare books and manuscripts, such as an original Gutenberg Bible and original books by [Erasmus](/wiki/Erasmus "Erasmus"), [Christophe Platin](/w/index.php?title=Christophe_Platin&action=edit&redlink=1 "Christophe Platin (page does not exist)") and [Aldus Manutius](/wiki/Aldus_Manutius "Aldus Manutius"). [Torre do Tombo](/wiki/Torre_do_Tombo_National_Archive "Torre do Tombo National Archive"), the [national archive](/wiki/National_archive "National archive"), is one of the most important archives in the world, with over 600 years and one of the oldest active Portuguese institutions. There are, among several others, the [Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino](/wiki/Arquivo_Hist%C3%B3rico_Ultramarino "Arquivo Histórico Ultramarino") and the Arquivo Histórico Militar.  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Sports")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Estadio_da_Luz_2012.jpg/200px-Estadio_da_Luz_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Estadio_da_Luz_2012.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/AlvaladeXXI4.jpg/200px-AlvaladeXXI4.jpg)](/wiki/File:AlvaladeXXI4.jpg)  
[Estádio da Luz](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_da_Luz "Estádio da Luz") (top), home to [S.L. Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica"), and [Estádio José Alvalade](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Jos%C3%A9_Alvalade "Estádio José Alvalade") (bottom), home to [Sporting CP](/wiki/Sporting_CP "Sporting CP").

Lisbon has a long tradition in sports. It hosted several matches, including the [final](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004 "UEFA Euro 2004"), of the [UEFA Euro 2004](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004 "UEFA Euro 2004") championship. The city also played host to the final of the [2001 IAAF World Indoor Championships](/wiki/2001_IAAF_World_Indoor_Championships "2001 IAAF World Indoor Championships") and the [European Fencing Championships](/wiki/European_Fencing_Championships "European Fencing Championships") in 1983 and 1992, as well as the [2003 World Men's Handball Championship](/wiki/2003_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship "2003 World Men's Handball Championship"), and the [2008 European Judo Championships](/wiki/2008_European_Judo_Championships "2008 European Judo Championships"). From 2006 to 2008, Lisbon was the starting point for the [Dakar Rally](/wiki/Dakar_Rally "Dakar Rally"). The city hosted the [2014](/wiki/2014_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2014 UEFA Champions League Final") and [2020](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2020 UEFA Champions League Final") [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") finals. In 2008 and 2016, the city hosted the [European Triathlon Championships](/wiki/European_Triathlon_Championships "European Triathlon Championships"). Lisbon has a leg at the [Volvo Ocean Race](/wiki/Volvo_Ocean_Race "Volvo Ocean Race"). It is one of the potential host cities for the [2030 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2030_FIFA_World_Cup "2030 FIFA World Cup").  

### Football {#Football}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Football")\]

The city hosts three [association football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") clubs in Portugal's highest league, the [Primeira Liga](/wiki/Primeira_Liga "Primeira Liga"). [Sport Lisboa e Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica"), commonly known as simply *Benfica* , has won 38 league titles in addition to two [European Cups](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League"). Lisbon's second-most successful club is [Sporting Clube de Portugal](/wiki/Sporting_CP "Sporting CP") (commonly known as *Sporting* and often referred to as *Sporting Lisbon* abroad to prevent confusion with other teams with the same name), winner of 20 league titles and the [UEFA Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup"). A third club, [C.F. Os Belenenses](/wiki/C.F._Os_Belenenses "C.F. Os Belenenses") (commonly *Belenenses* or *Belenenses Lisbon* ), based in the [Belém](/wiki/Bel%C3%A9m,_Lisbon "Belém, Lisbon") quarter, has solely won one league title. Other major clubs in Lisbon include [Atlético](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Clube_de_Portugal "Atlético Clube de Portugal"), [Casa Pia](/wiki/Casa_Pia_A.C. "Casa Pia A.C."), and [Oriental](/wiki/Clube_Oriental_de_Lisboa "Clube Oriental de Lisboa").

Lisbon has two [UEFA category four stadiums](/wiki/UEFA_elite_stadium "UEFA elite stadium"); Benfica's [Estádio da Luz](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_da_Luz "Estádio da Luz") (*Stadium of Light* ), with a capacity of over 65,000 and Sporting's [Estádio José Alvalade](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Jos%C3%A9_Alvalade "Estádio José Alvalade"), with a capacity of over 50,000. The Estádio da Luz held both the [2014](/wiki/2014_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2014 UEFA Champions League Final") and [2020 UEFA Champions League Final](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_Final "2020 UEFA Champions League Final"). There is also Belenenses' [Estádio do Restelo](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Restelo "Estádio do Restelo"), with a capacity of over 19,000. The [Estádio Nacional](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_Nacional "Estádio Nacional"), in nearby [Oeiras](/wiki/Oeiras_Municipality,_Portugal "Oeiras Municipality, Portugal"), has a capacity of 37,000 and was used exclusively for [Portuguese](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football team") international football matches and cup finals until the construction of larger stadia in the city. It held the [1967 European Cup Final](/wiki/1967_European_Cup_Final "1967 European Cup Final").  

### Other sports {#Other_sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Other sports")\]

Other sports, such as [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [futsal](/wiki/Futsal "Futsal"), [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball"), [roller hockey](/wiki/Roller_hockey_(quad) "Roller hockey (quad)"), [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") and [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball") are also popular; the latter's national stadium is in Lisbon. There are many other sports facilities in Lisbon, ranging from athletics, sailing, golfing to [mountain-biking](/wiki/Mountain-biking "Mountain-biking"). Lisboa and Troia golf course are two of many stunning [golf courses](/wiki/Golf_course "Golf course") located in Lisbon. Every March the city hosts the [Lisbon Half Marathon](/wiki/Lisbon_Half_Marathon "Lisbon Half Marathon"), while in September the [Portugal Half Marathon](/wiki/Portugal_Half_Marathon "Portugal Half Marathon").

### Membership in organizations {#Membership_in_organizations}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Lisbon&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Membership in organizations")\]

From 12 October 1982, Lisbon is part of the [Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities](/wiki/Union_of_Ibero-American_Capital_Cities "Union of Ibero-American Capital Cities").^[\[200\]](#cite_note-TwinsAndCoop-200)^^[\[203\]](#cite_note-203)^{#cite_ref-203}

From 28 June 1985, Lisbon is part of the Union of Capital Cities of Portuguese Language, along with 22 other cities from Angola, Brazil, Cape Verde, China, East Timor, Guinea-Bissau, Mozambique, Portugal, and São Tomé and Príncipe.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-TwinsAndCoop-200)^^[\[204\]](#cite_note-204)^{#cite_ref-204}
